persons coming in, and sometimes none at all for hours—we have not many sailors come—it is quite out of the way for them—my shop is towards the barracks—I suppose I have no trowsers at all like these—I had never seen the prisoner before the 16th—it was on Tuesday the 19th that the policeman came to my shop to ask about these things—he did not search my premises—I was not in at all—I was called to Major Elgin's, and my boy was hanging up the things—these were before the door, and they came and took the things—as I was coming home I met the policeman and my boy going with these things—I heard that these had been stolen—I saw the prisoner before the Magistrate on the following Monday—no one came with the prisoner when he sold them—my boy, Barnard, was by when he did come—my boy has been with me about five months—I have a gas-light in the shop—we had just opened the shop—we close on Friday night and open on Saturday night—the prisoner bringing things that did belong to him I had no suspicion—if he had brought a watch or gold lace I should have said, "Sailors do not belong to gold lace"—the Magistrate asked me what dress the man had who brought the things—I said it was something of a lightish jacket and light trowsers, something like canvass—I said to him, "Why do you sell your trowsers, you wear a pair of light trowsers, these will be handy for you"—he said, "I am rather out of employment, and am short, but I shall soon get in a Government vessel"—the officer sent a note for me to go before the Magistrate—I had noticed one of the prisoner's cheeks appeared rather higher than the other, as if it were swollen—I did not describe him as having dark whiskers—I did not have any further conversation with the prisoner—I said to him, "Clothes are very cheap, I cannot give you I the price you want"—he said he bought them at Portsmouth.

MOSES BARNARD . I am in the service of Mr. Myers—I saw the pri
soner soner at his shop—I am sure it was the prisoner—that was on Satur
day evening, the 16th of Nov., about eight o'clock—he sold my master a waistcoat and trowsers—these are them.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you put any mark on the things? A. Not at the time he sold them, but I looked at the buttons—I saw them in the dock-yard, and I knew them by the buttons—my master has plenty more trowsers, but not sailors' trowsers—he does not deal much in sailors' things, but when the prisoner came he bought these of him—I cannot say that he has never bought of sailors before—I have lived with him five months—he has got blue waistcoats—I was standing at the door when the prisoner came—I was not in the shop—I did not hear what he said, but I know he sold the things—my master has told me not to listen to

what a person says to him—I am to stand before the door—I did not state that the prisoner had dark whiskers—I never raised my hand to my face and show that he had hair on his face, and it was black—I do not recol
lect lect Mr. Hodson—I had never seen the prisoner before the 16th—the pro
secutor and the officer came afterwards and saw the waistcoat hanging before the door—they asked me for the trowsers, and then took me to the Dock-yard—I looked over the sailors in the yard, and did not see the prisoner—the officer then called all the sailors from the ship, and I saw the prisoner—he had been down below in the ship, and was called up—the officer did not show him to me—he told me to look round on all the sailors to see which he was—I do not think he said, when the prisoner came up, "Is not this the man?"—directly I saw the prisoner I said, "This is the man"—the officer was standing by—I will swear he did not ask me whether that was not the man.
COURT. Q. How many sailors did you see? A. About fifty—no one said, "Is not that the man," but to look round, and I said, "This is the man."

WILLIAM SHEEAY (police-constable R 304.) I took the prisoner on board the Dædalus—the prosecutor pointed him out to me—the prosecutor and I had been in search of the clothes at pawnbrokers, and then we went. to Mr. Myers's shop and found the trowsers and waistcoat, which he gave into my charge—Barnard then went down with me to the yard—we went on board the Hebe hulk—I asked the master-at-arms where the hands were—presently the prisoner came up with eight or ten sailors more—I asked Barnard if he saw him amongst them—he said, "That is the man," pointing to the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the lieutenant there? A. Yes; he said nothing to me or to Barnett about the prisoner—there were six or eight seamen on board, and then the prisoner came up—I did not see him come up, but presently I turned round and saw him standing there, and I asked Barnard whether he could point out the man—I heard nobody tell him anything about him but myself—I will swear no one said, "Is that the man."

EMILY WATTS . I am the wife of William Watts, who is employed as a caulker at Woolwich Dock-yard—I know the prosecutor and the ship's company of the Hebe—I went on board last Monday week—I saw the prosecutor—he made me tea on board.
Cross-examined. Q. How often had you been on board? A. That was the first time—I have been once since then.

HENRY HARVEY HODSON . I keep the Royal Mortar tavern at Wool
wich. I have known the prisoner five years—he lived in my house—his character has been as good as any boy I know—he was at my house on Saturday evening, the 16th—I cannot tell what time it was—I know his clothing so well that I am positive he never was possessed of a light jacket—his sister lived as cook in my house a number of years—she married, and then this poor boy was thrown on the world, and he was in my house for weeks and weeks—I think he was in my house on Saturday night, the 16th, about eight o'clock—he had a dress on similar to what he has now—he had no light jacket—Myers's house is nearly a mile from my house.

COURT. Q. Do you know what trowsers he had on? A. I do not, but I believe they were those he has now—they were lightish, but are now, from wear, rather brown—he had on the same dress he has now—I saw him at my house about eight o'clock—he was in the kitchen with the servant—he has known the servant ever since he was a child—I have to pass the kitchen frequently, and the door is generally open—I saw him there two or three times within half-an-hour—I think when I first saw him it was a quarter or twenty minutes before eight o'clock—he was in the habit of coming to my house of an evening when he had permission to leave the vessel—I recollect the day the prisoner was at my house, from the circumstance of the accusation, and then I recollected it was on the Saturday, from a conversation that took place in my coffee-room on the same evening, which caused me to come out to ask a question in my bar, and then I saw the prisoner, and I think that was before eight o'clock—none of my servants are here.

JAMES CANNON . I am a labourer to Mr. Watts, the high-constable. I have known the prisoner about two years—he was always a very good character, and very honest—I remember seeing him on Saturday evening, the 16th of Nov., about half-past seven o'clock—he had a pair of canvas trowsers, painted brown, and a blue frock.

COURT. Q. Where did you see him? A. At the Coach and Horses, and from there he went to Mr. Hodson's—we had a couple of pots of beer together, and the prosecutor too—he had not left him then—we came back again to the Coach and Horses—we met Stevens there, and then we all went together to Whale's, and had some drink.

ELLEN WHALES . I live right opposite the Ship and Half Moon, at Woolwich; I am married. The prisoner has been with me, off and on, for about five years—he has been honest—he was at my house that Saturday evening about a quarter after nine o'clock—he had lightish trowsers on, and a blue frock, tucked inside his trowsers, the very same as he has on now.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

170.
DAVID BURFOOT was indicted
for an attempt to commit an unnatural offence.
NOT GUILTY .

171.
JANE CATTERMORE was indicted
for stealing 1 shawl, value 3s.; and 13 yards of ribbon, 6s.; the goods of
John Buckland, her master.

JOHN BUCKLAND . I live in Crosby-row, Walworth-road; the prisoner has been in my service about six weeks. In consequence of some suspicion, I sent for a policeman—her box was examined in her presence—she un
locked locked it—I found a shawl of mine in it—in consequence of that I dis
charged her—she went away, leaving her box behind—on the following day I made a further search of her box—(I did not search further at first,

as my wife was in a delicate state of health)—the key of it was lying in the house—I then found another shawl, a silk dress, and two pieces of gauze ribbon—I know the ribbons to be mine by a private mark on them—the shawl I know to be my wife's from her wearing it—the prisoner's mother came with her next day to beg I would look over it, but having found these additional things, I gave her in charge—these are the things—the letter "S" is on one piece of ribbon, and the letter "L" with 'two strokes on the other—I am a dealer in these articles—the prisoner was not present when the ribbon was found; I had sent her away the day before—it was not in the power of any one to put anything into her box after she was gone—I had missed the ribbon long before—I had put the key on the mantel—shelf in the sitting-room—my wife and a little servant-girl had ac-cess to that room—they are not here—the prisoner offered no defence to the shawl being in her box—she said she took the shawl out of the closet in one of the upper rooms, and she said she was very sorry.

HENRY SCOTT (police-constable P 241.) I took the prisoner into cus-tody on the prosecutor's charge—I went up with him, and saw the two pieces of ribbon—he took them out of the box, and handed them to me—the box was unlocked—the prisoner was not present—she was not in the house—I received the shawl from the prosecutor also.

Prisoner's Defence. I took the shawl out of the closet in the shop
boy's bedroom, where there were some old things; I did not think it would be missed; the two pieces of ribbon I took out of the show-room, when I was cleaning it in the morning.

JOHN BUCKLAND
re-examined. The shawl was taken from the upper room—it was not thrown by, as not to be used again—the value of the ribbon is about 6s., as near as I can form an idea, and the shawl 3s.—I have inquired as to her former character, and believe her to be led away by the vanity of dress—there was much more valuable property within her reach.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—

div1.p:
172.
MARY CRISP was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Nov., 4 pairs of clogs, value 2s. 6d.; 2 candlesticks, 2s.; 1 metal tap and key, 1s.; 1 pair of snuffers, 2d.; 1 extinguisher, 3d.; 3 printed books, 6d.; 1 nutmeg-grater, 2d.; 1 towel, 6d.; 1 pinafore, 6d.; 1 neckerchief, 1s.; 1 smelling-bottle, 3d.; 2 watch-glasses, 6d.; 1 handkerchief, 6d.; 1 neck
lace, 4s.; 1 teetotum, 2d.; 1 iron box, 2s.; 1 pair of sugar-clippers, 2s.; 1 pair of spectacles, 6d.; 1 tray, 6d.; 1 napkin, 1s.; 2 tin biscuit-cutters, 1d.; 11 skewers, 6d.; 2 ink-glasses, 6d.; 1 ring, 3s.; 1 breast-pin, 1s.; 1 spoon, 2s.; and 1 penknife, 3d.; the goods of
Frederick Barnes, her master.

FREDERICK BARNES . I am a watch and clock maker, and live in Blen
heim-place, High-street, Peckham. The prisoner was in my service about a month—I had not been engaged in business at Peckham above a fort
night—I carry on business at Farningham, in Suffolk—the prisoner was about to leave me—in consequence of having missed two tea-spoons I re
quired to see her boxes—she would not allow me to see them—I went out, called on somebody, and on my return I found the constable with the pri
soner in custody—her box was with her—they were coming towards my house—I saw her box searched by the constable a my house, and found a

variety of shop goods in it, to the value of about 30s.—she had been en
gaged with me and my apprentice in removing goods from the house into the shop—the box contained the articles stated—these now produced ✗ them—some of them have my marks on them—these candlesticks have—I did not miss them till the box was searched—these candlesticks I had from Birmingham—I had seen them perhaps about a week before they were taken, when I marked them—the prisoner and my apprentice as
sisted in removing them from the sitting-room into the shop—this box-✗ I missed from my stock—it is the same size and exactly corresponds with it, and is made by the same maker—I had such things as all these in my stock—my mark is not on this iron—the paper was taken off—I know the candlesticks to be mine, and I believe the rest to be mine—some have my mark and some have not.

WILLIUM HAMMOND (police-constable P 90.) On Friday evening, the 15th of Nov., I was called by Mrs. Barnes into the shop—while speaking to her the prisoner came in—I heard Mrs. Barnes ask her why she took her box away—she said because she wanted to book her place to go by the eight o'clock buss to Charing-cross—she ran out at the door, down to where she had taken her box, about fifty yards from Mr. Barnes's—I followed—she took her box from there—I took her into custody as she was turning the things out of her box into the chandler's shop—I stopped her from doing so, put the things back into the box, and took her and the box to Mr. Barnes's—on getting there the things now produced were found in her box—she said she had bought some of them at two or three shops above there—I found this silver spoon in her hand, a little knife, and this necklace.

FREDERICK BARNES
re-examined. I cannot swear to the spoon—it is such a one as I had in use—I know these beads—I missed some, and these match exactly with them.

Prisoner. My mistress would not pay me my wages; she told me she should not pay me a farthing; I went up stairs in an obstinate humour, and did put the things into my box, I own; she took me more than 100 miles from home.

MR. BARNES. I told her I did not think she ought to be leaving me as she did, but I was going to pay her just before this robbery was found out—she said she had no fault to find with my mistress or me, but she did not like Peckham—I did not turn her away—we should have been glad to have had her stop if she had done right.
Prisoner. My mistress told me I might help myself, for I should not have a farthing of wages; I had no fault to find with my master or mistress, but I did not like Peckham.

MR. BARNES. I have no reason to believe that my wife told her to help herself—my wife has money—I do not know that she always has money by her—I suppose she had sufficient, but I do not know how it was at that time—I understood the prisoner to bear a very good character when I took her—her friends are very respectable—I do not know what wages she was to have.
Prisoner. My last mistress gave me 3l., but said she would give me 5l. if I would stop; Mrs. Barnes said she would give me 6l. a year if I would come up with them.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—

div1.p:
173.
GEORGE JOHN PAGE was indicted
for stealing 4 feet of brass tubing, value 4s. 6d.; 2 iron drills, 1s.; and 2 iron brackets, 2s.; the goods of the
London and South Western Railway Company, his masters.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE WILLIAMS (police-constable V 97.) In the morning of last Saturday week I went with Dalby and Ratcliff to No. 56, Wickham-street, Vauxhall—Ratcliff went up stairs and brought the prisoner down—I staid below—I then asked him to accompany me up stairs while I searched his bedroom—I found nothing there—the prisoner said, "It is no use looking here, you will find nothing; if you don't look into the box that is down in the back room I will give you a sovereign"—I went down stain where Dalby and Ratcliff were placed, and found a box there—it was locked—I asked the prisoner if that was his box—he said it was—I asked if he would be so good as to unlock it—he said he had not got the key—I said I should break it open—I did so, and found three large pieces of brass tubing, which I produce, and some drills and a screw-wrench were taken out of the box by Dalby—I then took the prisoner into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. NEALE. Q. What was the exact hour when you searched his bed-room? A. Between seven and eight o'clock in the morning—when Ratcliff brought him down, I told him what I came for—I searched the lower part of the house—there were two rooms in the lower part—his wife was there, and two children, I believe—there was no lodger that I know of—I partly searched the, rooms—I had previously gone up stairs with the prisoner, and, searched his bedroom—I told him we had come to take, him into custody, for offering some brass tubing for sale, and we had come to search his house—he then said, "It is no use your searching here, you will not find anything; if you don't search the box that is down stairs I will give you a sovereign"—no one was present then but the prisoner and myself—the sovereign was not given to me—I had just done searching the room when he said those words—he was pre-sent when we searched below—I did not find any sovereign on his person, or in the house—the box was in the back room, which is a kitchen or workshop—I had been in the house about two minutes before I saw him coming down stairs.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long have you been an officer? A. Eight years and a half.

ROBERT RATCLIFF (police-constable V. 26.) I accompanied Williams and Dalby to the prisoner's house—I went into the bedroom, found the pri-soner in bed, and took him into custody—under a carpenter's bench in his workshop I found two iron brackets—when I was taking him to the sta-tion, he said some person must have put the, brass tubes into his pocket—he did not tell me how they got into his box.

JASPER B. DALBY . I am superintendent of the South-Western Rail
way police—I know the prisoner—he was not employed last Saturday week on the railway—I accompanied the other two officers to his house on the day in question, and saw the articles found—>as Ratcliff was lifting the brass tubing out of the box, he said, "Ah, there it is, there it is, but I can't help it; if money will settle it, you shall have it; but I will bring no one else in besides myself."
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been superintendent on this railway? A. A year and ten months—I may have seen the prisoner at

work there, but there are so many men—I was present when the prisoner was asked for the key of the box—he said he had not got one—as Rat
cliff was taking him out of the house he handed this key to his wife which I took charge of, and it fitted the box in question—I tried it.

JOHN LANGTHORN . I am one of the engineers employed at the South-Western Railway terminus, at Nine Elms—the prisoner has heen in the Company's service, I think, nearly three years, as a carpenter—the Com
pany had such brass tubing as this produced, for the purposes of the engine—the prisoner used to work close to where this was put—it is part of the tubing introduced into the boiler, for the steam to pass through, by which notice is given of any eruption.

Cross-examined. Q. This is a patent of one of the makers of the loco-motive? A. Yes, all the locomotives have tubing, but not the same as ours—this is the last patent—I don't know whose patent it is—it may be used on other railways—I believe the prisoner has always borne a good character.

CHARLES BUSH . I am a smith. I made two iron brackets similar to these produced, for the prisoner, to put in a coke-wagon on the railway—to the best of my knowledge it was in Oct.—I never made more than two for the Company, to my knowledge.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been in the service? A. Six years—the prisoner has been there three years, and always bore a good character—there are no marks about these brackets by which I can swear to them—I cannot swear they are my work—I do not know how many hundred coke-wagons there are on the railway—there are nine smiths in the same shop with myself—I never saw any brackets of this description made—I have made other kinds—I cannot swear these are what I made in Oct.—they are very much like them, but there are many smiths besides myself that make them.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you ever seen any two brackets of that form manufactured at the railway, except the two you made? A. No, and they were to repair a coke-wagon with.

HENRY BAKER . I am a brazier, employed by the South-Western Rail
way Company, at Nine Elms. In Nov. I worked at 128 brass tubes to fit this gauge—the prisoner worked about twenty yards from me—I produce one of the tubes which I so prepared—the broken pieces produced, to the best of my knowledge, have been prepared by me to fit this gauge—(The witness here fitted the tubing to the gauge)—it fits this gauge—the mouths were made smaller to fit the fire-box of the engine—these three pieces at one time formed one entire piece, but the whole length is not here—it is altogether useless in this state, except as old brass—a whole one would cost about 15s. or 16s.

Cross-examined. Q. You do not swear to these pieces? A. No—I have been a year and ten months on this railway—I formerly worked on the Northern and Eastern—I have been accustomed to make these sort of tubes about seven years—I never made any of this exact kind before—they have come up within the last two years and a half—I have seen them before I came on this railway, but not of this size—there are different diameters—they are used on other railways, but not of this gauge—I could not speak to it without the gauge—if tubing of the same gauge used on other railways was produced, I could not tell it from this.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had the prisoner anything to do with your brass rods? A. Not the least.
JOHN DOWLINO . I am foreman of the locomotive department. These two drills bear the initials of the London and South-Western Railway on them.

Cross-examined. Q. Did the prisoner come from the Northern and Eastern Railway Company? A. Yes—he has been a very attentive ser
vant, and everything I could wish him to be.
Confined Two Months .

174.
JAMES JOHNSON was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Samuel John Weldon, about the hour of five in the night of the 13th of Nov., at Bermondsey, with intent to steal.

SAMUEL JOHN WELDON . I live in Bermondsey-road, in the parish of Bermondsey—I occupy the whole house. I was disturbed in the night of the 13th of Nov., by the barking of my dog—I got up, opened the door, and listened—I did not find the staircase-window open then—I did after
wards, about half-past three o'clock—I immediately sprang my rattle, and let the police in at the front door—I found the sash of the kitchen win
dow broken, also four panes of glass—there was room for a man to get in—the sash frame was carried out with the glass, and I found some marks of blood on the window-blind, such as might occur from a person's hand being cut—I am in the habit of keeping the staircase window always closed, and I know of no alteration in that respect that night—I did not notice that it was fastened, but it was decidedly down—some flower
pots which had been at the staircase-window, I found removed into the garden, as if they had been handed down—I lost no property—it appeared to me that the parties had entered by the staircase-window, and gone out by the kitchen-window.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How did that appear? A. By the broken sash in the kitchen, and the staircase window was half open when I sprung my rattle—if the man had entered at the front, he must have made a noise, and I should have heard it—the kitchen window is at the front—I did not hear him go out—I did not hear the windows opened—my name is Samuel John—my usual name is John—I have not used the name of Samuel for a long time—few persons know me by that name—my wife does, but no one else, I apprehend—I was never called Samuel as a child—the name was given me, I believe, by my godfathers—I never knew myself called by that name—I never sign my name Samuel, only John—I know I was christened Samuel, because I have seen my baptismal certificate—I have never used the name in matters of import
ance, where I have had to sign my name correctly—I did not use it when I was married—my godfathers have been dead many years—it is nearly sixty years ago that I first heard that my name was Samuel—I have seldom or ever had the name attributed to me since, in fact, never, to my know
ledge—it was my baptismal certificate that informed me my name was Samuel—I have not got it with me—I can swear that my name is Samuel—I have not examined the register of baptisms—my father left no will, nor is there any family document in which I am recognised as Samuel—I have never signed the name of Samuel—I mentioned it here, in consequence of being asked if I had more than one name—I
mentioned John only, as I have been in the constant habit of signing every document in that name.
NOT GUILTY .

Before
Edward Bullock, Esq.

175.
DANIEL CONNER was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Oct., 2 sheets, value 7s.; 3 shirts, 9s.; 1 shift, 2s.; 1 pair of stocking, 1s.; 1 towel, 1s.; and 1 copper, 10s.; the goods of
John Gault, the copper being fixed to a certain building: 2nd COUNT, not stating it to be fixed.
MR. HORRY conducted the Prosecution.

MARY GAULT . I am the wife of John Gault, who is in the employ of the Brighton Railway Company—we live at No. 35, in the Maze, Borough. On the 2nd of Oct. I hung out some clothes in my yard, and saw them safe at nine o'clock at night—I fastened the back door, and at that time the copper was safe in the back-kitchen—the door was only latched—the policeman brought the clothes to me at near two o'clock in the morning—they they were the articles stated, and are all my husband's property—the pri
soner was then in custody—I missed the copper—it had been fixed with mortar and bricks—it has since been refixed.

THOMAS CROCKETT . I am a salesman in the Borough-market, and live at No. 36, in the Maze, next door to the prosecutor. On the 24th of Oct., I was disturbed about half-past one o'clock in the morning, and beard a something rumbling in the passage between my house and the prosecu
tor's—it sounded to me like copper—I got but of bed, threw up the window, and saw a man who had just passed my window a little to the left—I then saw a second person, the prisoner, come out of the passage—I hallooed out, "Halloo, mate, what is up there?"—he made no answer—I sprang my rattle, and the policeman flew to the corner—the prisoner was met by the police in less than five minutes, and brought back.
COURT. Q. Had you ever seen him before? A. Not to my knowledge—I did not see him taken, but saw him brought back in five minutes—I am sure he is the person I saw come out of the passage.

GEORGE TOMPKINS , (police-constable M 166.) On the night of the 23rd of Oct. I heard a rattle spring—I went towards the sound, and met the prisoner in Tooley-street, just at the end of the Maze, not a great distance from the passage—he was carrying a bundle, containing sheets, and other linen, wet—I stopped him, and took him back to Mrs. Gault's house—she identified the articles—most of them have been returned to her—as I was taking him back, Crockett was at his window, and identified him in a moment.

GEORGE ADAMS (police-constable M 156.) I was on duty in Tooley-street on this night—I heard the rattle spring, and went to the spot—in consequence of something I heard, I looked for the copper, and found it in a mews, right opposite the prosecutor's, concealed under a block or washing stool—Mrs. Gault identified it—I did not fit it.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming home about half-past one o'clock; I live in the same street; a young man asked me if I would carry a bundle from the Maze; I said I would; he gave it me, and told me to go on, and when I got to the top of the Maze the policeman stopped me, and said, "What have you got?" I said, "I don't know; I have just had it given me to carry."

GUILTY of stealing only.** Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Recorder.

176.
WILLIAM DIXON was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Nov., 1 breast-pin, value 3l., the goods of
William Hughes.

WILLIAM HUGHES . I am a jeweller, and live at No. 117, High-street, Southwark. The prisoner came to my shop on Tuesday, the 19th of Nov., to examine some pins—he looked at some diamond pins, and selected one, on which he left 1s. deposit, stating that his brother would call in the morning and pay the difference—the price of that pin was 2l. 12s.—after he had left the shop we looked over the cushion and discovered a pin of the value of 35s. missing—he came again the following morning to look at some more diamond pins—my suspicions were naturally aroused, and I counted the number, which was eighteen, and placed them on a cushion before him—during the time a customer came into the shop, and entered into conversation—the prisoner also entered into conversation with him—while the gentleman was in conversation with me, the prisoner took one diamond pin from off the cushion, and secreted it up his sleeve—I saw him—immediately after he had done so, he called my attention to one of the pins which he had previously been looking at, and wished me to send that pin to his brother's house—he particularly wished I should bring it myself with the pin on which he had left the deposit the day before—I took down the address which he gave me, "No. 5, Mary Ann-place, South
ward bridge-road," which I afterwards discovered to be a fictitious address—I counted the pins after I had seen him put the one up his sleeve, and there were only seventeen—while taking the address down, I rang the bell for my assistant—the prisoner still had the diamond pin up his sleeve—I could not see it up his sleeve, but I am quite positive he put it there—I called my assistant twice after that, and while calling him the prisoner dropped the pin from his sleeve on to a ledge on the counter—I am quite positive of that, and I am quite positive the pin had not been there pre
vious to my calling my assistant, for I bad distinctly seen the spot where the pin was afterwards found, and there was nothing on it—I did not hear the pin fall—I charged him then with having taken the pin, and also one the day before, and I said in a hurried manner, "If you will give me back the one you took the day before, I will not send for a policeman—he denied it, and I immediately sent for a policeman, and gave him into custody—I went to No. 5, Mary Ann-place, and they knew no such person as Mr. Henry Dixon—the landlord said a Mr. V. Jay did live at the house, but no Mr. Henry Dixon—the prisoner had said I was to take them to Mr. V. Jay, and ask for Mr. Henry Dixon, who was his brother—I have nobody here from that house.

Prisoner. Q. Who was in the shop the second day I went there? A. My assistant when you first came in—a gentleman came in while you were there; he looked at the pins on the cushion, made some remarks on the colour of the stones, and took them to the door to look at them, but the one you put up your sleeve was not then on the cushion—I will swear he never touched that pin—what pins the gentleman looked at were taken off the cushion—this one was on the cushion—the gentleman had not the opportunity of taking the pin as well as you—there were eighteen pins after he left—he could have removed the pin certainly, but he did not—he left before you—I said if you would restore me the pin you had stolen the day before, or its value, I would not give you into custody—I counted the pins when I took them out of the window and put them before you—I

had time to do so—they were placed one, two, three, four, and five, so that I could count them—I counted them five or six times while on the counter, expecting every time to miss one—when you had put the pin up your sleeve I had an opportunity of looking along the ledge where you afterwards placed it—I could see it was not there—you were going out, and I was anxious to prevent it—I could not see the ledge when I was behind the counter—the gentleman had left the shop before you put the pin there—I did not see you put it there—I saw you put it up your sleeve—I did not count the pins at the time I took them out of the window the first day, or I should have discovered it—it was the second day—there was eighteen—I did not count them the first day, but one particular pin marked 35s. was gone—that is how I know it was missing—the depositions were not taken down in Court before you on Wednesday—when you were taken up I asked Mr. Cottingham to be kind enough to remand you that I might go round to the trade, thinking I might discover some other case, and I found you had taken two pins from Mr. Hayes, of Farringdon-street, and had only come out of prison four days—the officer from Giltspur-street gave me that information—I counted my pins at the time I gave you into custody, and told you there were only seventeen—no pin was found on you—I saw you place the pin up your sleeve—I did not see it when it was up there.

GEORGE TOMKINS (police-constable M 166.) I received charge of the prisoner at the prosecutor's shop, with the pin he was charged with secret
ing ing there—I have it here—I went to the address the prosecutor repre
sented the prisoner had given, and found no such name as Dixon known there.

Prisoner's Defence. I would first call your attention to the manner in which the prosecutor acts towards me when he accuses me of felony. He first endeavours to extort money from me by threatening to give me in charge for felony, and because I would not compromise the matter for 35s. he gives me in custody. He says himself he offered to compromise it; surely you cannot believe that that man comes here for justice, for he offers to compromise the matter; does he want justice, or to compromise jus
tice? if he is a respectable man, and no doubt he is, as the keeper of a jeweller's shop, does it show respectability on his part to attempt to com
pound a felony? I know nothing of the law myself, or perhaps he would be liable to punishment for it. I shall leave it in your hands. My friends are respectable and monied persons, but I did not wish them to know where I was, or to have my name in the public papers, which induced me to give a false name when I was taken up. I can refer to Davis and Company, furriers, Bull's Head Court; they know my father very well. I wrote to my father, saying that I was in difficulty, but have not let him know where I am. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court. I fully expect if I am brought in guilty, that I shall be transported; the officers of Newgate have many of them told me so.

GUILTY.* Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Baron Alderson.

177.
EDWARD FAITHFULL was indicted
for a rape.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

178.
SARAH HEELAN was indicted
for feloniously killing and slay
ing
James Lonergan.
MR. CURWOOD conducted the Prosecution.

MARY KENNEDY . I live in Mulgrave-place, Woolwich. I have known the prisoner for about the last four or five months—I live in the room over her—she has two sons, and had a little boy named Lonergan in her care—on Wednesday, the 16th of Oct., I remember that little boy coming down to me—he then appeared well in health—he asked me for a light and a drink of water—I opened the door to let him out of my washhouse—he appeared in good health.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When did the child die? A. I cannot exactly say—I never saw it dead—the last time I saw him was on Thursday, the 17th, about five o'clock—Mrs. Mead brought him up in her arms, and I was frightened at its appearance—I did not observe that it had any eruption—I turned my head away and did not see its face—the prisoner had always been very kind to the child, and kept it very com
fortable—she was very attentive to her own children, and to that too for the last four weeks—she treated it with equal kindness as her own children.

JAMES PARRY (police-sergeant R 8.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody on the 19th of Oct.—I first spoke to her son, who is eight or nine years old, in her presence, and said, "Show me where your mother hit little Jemmy's head"—the child went to the door with me to show me where the child was struck—the prisoner, in two or three minutes, said, "Here is where it was"—she took me into the room and said, "The child fell off this box," which was a box about eighteen inches high.

COURT. Q. Was it possible to have fallen from that box and struck its head against the corner of the box? A. Yes—the child pointed out the door as the place against which its head was struck—the door is not a foot from the box—the prisoner said it had fallen off the box, and struck its head against the corner—that might have been so if there was only one injury on the head, but there were three—after taking her to the station-house some friends came to see her, and as she returned to the cell she sighed and said, "Oh, poor little fellow! he hit his head against the iron pot."
(MR. CURWOOD here stated that he had no evidence to contradict the prisoner's statement, and declined calling further witnesses.)
NOT GUILTY .

Before
Edward Bullock, Esq.

179.
WILLIAM LOVETT was indicted
for unlawfully breaking and entering the dwelling of
Margaret Nelson, with intent to steal; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months .
Before Mr. Baron Alderson.

180.
ELLEN M'CARTY, alias Horne
, was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin, having been previously convicted of a like offence.
MR. CHAMBERS conducted the Prosecution.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am assistant solicitor to the Royal Mint. I produce a copy of the record of the conviction of Ellen M'Carty at this Court, in the August Session, 1848—(read.)
EDMUND MATTHEWS . I was a police-constable. In August, 1848, I attended in the New Court, and was present at the prisoner's trial for uttering three counterfeit shillings—I know her well.

Prisoner. He knew me before I was used to anything of the kind, and spoke in my favour before. Witness. It is twelve or fifteen yean ago since I knew her, and seven or eight years ago since I missed her.

SARAH COSNIGHT . My husband is a coal
dealer, and lives in Mason-street, Lambeth. On Saturday evening, the 16th of Nov., between eight and nine o'clock, the prisoner came and ordered a 1/4 cwt. of coals, which would come to 4 3/4 d., and told me to send them to John-street—she did not give me the number—I do not know of any John-street in the neighbourhood—she gave me a half-crown in payment—I discovered it was bad immediately, and handed it over to my husband—she was takes into custody immediately.

Prisoner. She handed the half-crown to a woman who came in, and asked her opinion of it—she then gave it to her husband, and he said it was bad. Witness. It never went out of my hand, only to my husband—I never asked anybody's opinion on it.
RICHARD COSNIGHT . I received the half-crown from my wife—I kept it till Daviet, the officer, came and took her into custody, and then gave it to him.
JOHN DAVIES (police-constable L 46.) I took the prisoner—Mr. Cosnight gave me the half-crown, which I produce—the prisoner was searched by a female.

JOHN HATCHETT . I am a green-grocer, and keep a coal-shed in Royal-street, Lambeth—on Friday night, the 8th of Nov., about a quarter to nine o'clock, the prisoner came and ordered a 1/4 cwt. of coals to be sent to No. 14, Hosier-street—I said there was no such street, she most mean Crozier-street—she said she did—the coals came to 4 3/4 d.—she gave me half-a-crown in payment—I gave her the change, and she went away—I took the coals to No. 14, Crozier-street, and found none had been ordered, nor any such person as the prisoner known there—she gave me no name—I then looked at the half-crown, and found it was bad—I chop
ped it up, and threw it away—I am certain it was the one the prisoner gave me—I had no other.

Prisoner. Q. Are you sure I am the person? A. I am quite sure-Goff, the policeman, did not tell me to recognise you—I recognised you✗ before he spoke to me—he did not tell me I should be well paid for my trouble.

DINAH HAYNES . I am a coal-dealer, and live in Little Surrey-street. On Saturday, the 9th of Nov., between six and seven o'clock in the even
ing, ing, the prisoner came and ordered 1/4 cwt. of coals, to go to No. 10, Union-street—they came to 4 1/2 d., she gave me a half-crown, and I gave her 2s. 1 1/2 d. change—I kept the half-crown in my hand, and directly she had left the shop I found it was bad, from the feel—I weighed the coals directly, and took them and the half-crown to No. 10, Union-street, but no coals had been ordered there—I gave Lawrence the same half-crown—I had no other.
Prisoner. I never saw this woman till I saw her at Union-hall
Witness. I am sure she is the person—I had never seen her before—she was a few minutes in my company—I hare no doubt of her.

SAMUEL THOMAS LAWRENCE . Mrs. Haynes save me a half-crown—I showed it to Mrs. Saunders, and afterwards to Mr. Price—he compared it with a good one, marked it, and returned it to me—I saw him mark it on the edge with a good half-crown—he rubbed it—I gave it to Sergeant Brown at the station—this now produced is it—here is the mark—it is the one I received from Mrs. Haynes.
Prisoner. That is not the evidence he gave against me at the office.

Witness. After I received it from Mrs. Haynes I put it into a quart pot, and left it there all night—I took it out again in the morning, and when Mr. Price called in I showed it to him, and said, "Here is a good half-crown for you"—he said, "It is a very good one, I will give you change for it"—I said, "You had better be careful"—he looked at it, and sounded it—he looked at it for about ten minutes, and would not believe it was a bad one—he then took a good half-crown, and rubbed the edge of the other against it—he then said it was bad—I am certain this is the same—I had marked it with a pencil before I put it into the quart pot, the the mark was on it when I took it out in the morning—it has been rubbed out since.
Prisoner. He did not mention about the pencil-mark at Union-hall.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. This half-crown, uttered to Mrs. Cosnight, is counterfeit, also the one just produced, and both have been cast in the same mould.
Prisoner's Defence. I leave myself to the mercy of the Judge and Jury. I can assure you I am not guilty of giving the half-crown that was put into the quart pot.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years .

181.
SAMUEL SIMS was indicted
for feloniously killing and slay
ing
Edward Everest the elder: he was also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the like offence.
MESSRS. BALLANTINE and WILDE conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN PRIOR . I am a labourer, and live at No. 152, Rotherhithe-street. On the Sunday morning I found the body of Edward Everest—I took him ashore, and delivered him into the hands of his friends and the beadle.

EDWARD EVEREST . I am an inspector of the Thames police—the de
ceased wan my father—he was a waterman, and had been so many years—he was sixty-six years of age. I was on the Surrey shore on the 25th of Oct., about ten minutes before ten o'clock in the morning, and saw him leave the Surrey shore about thirteen or fourteen minutes before ten, with four persons in a skiff with him—it was a boat of such a size as he could manage properly—I was standing on the causeway at Church-stairs, Ro
therhithe—the tide was nearly half flood—this was in the Pool—after he had left I noticed the Waterman steamer, No. 6—it was coming up with the tide, and going at the rate of eight or nine miles an hour, in my opinion—the proper rate for steamers navigating the Pool is about five miles an hour—the Waterman is a Woolwich boat—at the time I first saw the Water
man coming up, my father was, I should say, better thun two-thirds across the water, and about 150 yards from the steamer—I lost sight of my father's boat on my attention being called to the steamer—there was a tier of ves
sels between my father's boat and the steamer—there were about six

vessels in the tier at that time—there were no vessels whatever obstructing the channel of the river—the steamer seemed to be making a straight course for the Upper Tunnel-pier—that is not a slanting course from one pier to another—they take their course from below the Lower Tunnel-pier, in general—supposing she was coming from there, she would have to cross the river—she was going straight towards the Upper Tunnel-pier from where I saw her first, which was off King Edward's-stairs—that is, at the lower side of the Lower Tunnel-pier—the Tunnel stairs are on the Middle
sex side—when I first saw the steamer, her bows were slanting towards the Tunnel-pier—King Edward's-stairs are lower down the river than the Tunnel-pier, and on the Middlesex side—I observed the Waterman No. 6 making a very heavy careen on one side, leaning on one side, and I ob
served a skiff come under her stern momentarily afterwards, and saw three or four persons struggling in the water from the skiff—that was just above the Lower Tunnel-pier—they were going towards the Upper Tunnel-pier—there are two Tunnel piers, which are near about 100 yards apart—there was a schooner moored just above the Lower Tunnel-pier—I did not ob
serve the position of that schooner either then or afterwards—I went off in my own boat, came up to the skiff, and found it was my father's.

Q. After seeing this careen, did you notice anybody on the paddle-box? A. I did—it was the prisoner—it is usual to have a person on the paddle-box—he box—he directs the motions of the vessel—it is his duty to give the steers
man a signal which way he wishes the vessel to go—I saw my father's body on Saturday morning—his name was Edward Everest—there was no dimi
nution of the speed of the steamer before this careen.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What is the name of the stairs that are close in on the Lower Tunnel-pier? A. Wapping Dock-stairs—I believe those were the stairs my father was going to—I did not see the schooner till after the accident—Wapping Dock-stairs are very close to the Lower Tunnel-pier, and a boat going across the river to Wapping Dock-stairs would be shut in by the pier after she had got to a certain extent—if anything projected beyond the pier she would be more shut in.

JOHN SHADRACK . I am a seaman, formerly of the Valiant. On Friday, the 25th of Oct., I got into a boat on the Thames—there were five in the boat altogether with the person who was rowing—I did not know him—we were going over to Wapping Dock-stairs—as we were going along we met with a barge going up along the tide—I sang out, "Waterman, here is a barge coming," and he rowed astern of it—after that we met a schooner, and we went ahead of the schooner—after we had passed the schooner we saw a steamer coming up—we were sufficiently near to see the number—it was No. 6, Waterman—we were between 100 and 150 feet from the steamer, as near as I could judge—she was coming up along the tide—when I saw her, I stood up and waved my hand for them to keep more out into the middle of the river, which they did not—she did not make the least alteration in her course after I made that sign—I saw a person on the paddle-box—I do not know who it was—he saw me wave my hand—he had an opportunity of altering his course so as to keep more into the middle of the river—when the waterman saw the steamer coming he rowed as hard as he could—the steamer's stem nearly caught the boat, and knocked the scull out of the waterman's hand—he rowed round with his right hand, so that the steamer should not strike the boat right in the middle, so as to slant the boat along the steamer, and the fore part of the paddle-box struck

the fore part of the boat, turned her over, and we were all upset in the water—two lives were lost, and nearly the whole—as near as I could judge, the steamer was going at full speed, at the rate of ten miles an hour—I have been employed at sea nearly eight years—I can partly judge of the speed at which a boat is going, not exactly—I did not see any schooner.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you acquainted with steam-boats at all? A. No—I have not been much on the river.

JAMES MAYLOR . I am a seaman. I was on board this skiff on the 25th of Oct.—I saw the steamer coming up—at that time there was nothing between us and the steamer—she was coming at nine or ten knots an hour—I saw Shadrack get up and make a sign—there was a man on the paddle-box at that time—if he had put his helm a-starboard the least bit it would have cleared us—it came up to us—there was no lessening of speed that I noticed—the boatman pulled his right-hand oar—that was the proper course to adopt, or else the steamer would have cut the boat right in the middle—the stem of the paddle-box struck the boat, and it was overturned—I can swim—I attempted at first to swim to the steamer, but did not do so, because I saw that she was not stopping—her paddles were still in motion, but they might have been eased a little—I did not notice the schooner moored to the Lower Tunnel-pier, and have not seen it since—our skiff was not drawn by any current caused by anything near the shore—it was in no current at all, except the tide.

Cross-examined by SIR JOHN BAYLEY. Q. You say Shadrack hailed the steamer? A. He waved his hand—I did not hear the steamer hail us till she was close on us, and then they sang out, "Hoy"—that was just as the collision happened—it was too late then—we were about two or three barges' length from Wapping Dock-stairs, as near as I could judge.

THOMAS PALMER . I am a blacksmith. On Friday, the 25th of Oct., I was one of the four persons who were going over to Wapping Dock-stairs, in the boat rowed by the deceased—we saw the steam-boat coming up about 150 feet from us—a sailor, who was in the boat, stood up, and halloed out several times, and waved his hand several times—no notice was taken—the course of the steamer was not at all altered, nor the speed slackened—she struck our skiff, and we were all upset—the wheels of the steamer were in motion at the time the collision took place.
JURY. Q. Are you sure they were turning the usual way, and not turned the other way? A. No, they were turning towards our boat—I am quite lure of that.

Cross-examined by SIR JOHN BAYLEY. Q. Did you see the steamer give a sudden careen? A. Yes—that did not alter her course—I saw her coming up as fast when she struck our boat, as when I first saw her—my jaw was broken in three places on this occasion, and it hurts me very much now—the steamer went in towards the shore—she did not hail us—I did not see any one on board hail us—I heard somebody call out, "Stop her;" but whe
ther that came from the steamer or any small boat I cannot say—I heard that when she was about twenty or thirty feet from us—I was before the Coroner—there were some small boats on the river, and the cry of "Stop her" might have proceeded from them—I am sure it did not come from the steamer—(looking at his deposition)—this is my name and handwriting.
(The witness's deposition being read, stated, "When within ten or twenty feet of the steamer I heard some one on board that boat say, 'Stop her,'

&c. I thought the words 'Stop her' proceeded from the steamer, but I can
not tell.")
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you see the schooner ashore at the Lower Tunnel-pier? A. No.

WILLIAM JEFFORD . I am a waterman. On Friday, the 25th of Oct., I was on the Lower Tunnel-pier, and saw the Waterman, No. 6, coming up the river—she was going at the rate of eight or nine miles an hour—I do not know whether that is her full speed or not—there was a schooner moored to the Lower Tunnel-pier—I had moored her there some time before—I saw a skiff and a man rowing—the steam-boat struck it—she was not above her own length from the skiff when I first saw her—she was just on the point of striking—I did not see whether it had at all altered its direc
tion before it struck the boat—the skiff was twenty-one feet long—the speed of the steamer was not diminished to my sight—I had seen the steamer before—at the time I saw the skiff the steamer was going in the same direction as she had been before—she had not altered her course from the time I first saw her—when I first saw her she was about 150 feet from where I stood—it was not half a minute between my first seeing her and her striking the skiff—I have been acquainted with the river for some time.

Q. What is, in your judgment, the proper rate for going in the Pool? A. Four miles against the tide, I think it is; and six miles with it—I dare say the tide itself would drive a barge along at the rate of four miles an hour, with a person just now and then to straighten her or turn her round—in my judgment there ought to be an increase of only two miles an hour put on by the steamers—the schooner that I had moored caused some eddy; but at the time the skiff was overturned she had not come within the influence of that eddy.

Cross-examined by SIR JOHN BAYLET. Q. Are you employed at the Lower Tunnel-pier? A. Yes—the "Waterman" boats do not run to that pier—I did not see the steamer starboard her helm—she might have done so, in the course of the way she was going—I think she ought to have starboarded her helm, to have cleared the boat—I saw the schooner aground—she caused a little eddy above her—she caused more eddy when she was aground than when she was lifted—a good many steamers come to the Lower Tunnel-pier, as many as to the other—they travel at the same speed as the others—there is very little difference in any of them—one is as good as the other—there is never above a minute difference in speed in any of them—sometimes one is first, and sometimes the other is first.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I suppose you are only employed as a servant at this pier? A. That is all—I have no share or interest in the boats—I think if the helm had been starboarded, it would have enabled the steamer to avoid the boat.

JOHN CHAMBERS . I am a master mariner, belonging to the schooner Ann—on Friday, the 25th of October, she was lying at the Tunnel pier—whilst there I saw the skiff and steam-boat, and saw them come into colli
sion—the steam-boat was going, I should think, at about eight miles an hour, as near as I could judge, when she was passing our ship—when the boats came together I was, I should think, between eighty and ninety feet from them.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You were on board the schooner when this happened? A. Yes, on the quarter-deck—I had run ashore that morning—at the time in question my vessel was just lifted

astern, but was hard and fast by the head—her stern projected about ten feet beyond the Lower Tunnel-pier, as near as I can calculate—there were ropes made fast to the Tunnel pier—she is one hundred tons burden—her canvass was all struck and stowed—her boom projected about four feet over the stern—it is a smooth stern—we went there about high water about three o'clock in the morning, from some accident—we were going to discharge, and another vessel came and took her anchor up—about nine or ten in the morning we were lying with her stern right athwart the stream—I observed the steamer come up—I did not see the skiff till she was close to the steam-boat—she was about seventy or eighty feet from us, higher up the river, between the Upper and Lower Tunnel-pier, inside of us—there was a very strong eddy created by the position in which my schooner lay across the tide.

Q. Would the effect of that eddy, on a small boat, coming from the southward to the northward, if it got into it, be to carry it out again into the stream, instead of enabling it to go to Wapping Dock-stairs? A. Oh yes, and it would affect a ship as well as a small boat—I was in it no later than this passage up—if it had not been for the eddy I think the skiff would have made the stairs easily enough—I saw the skiff when she turned round in the eddy, towards the steam-boat—that was the effect of the eddy on her—that eddy would not be perceivable to a vessel coming straight up the river, not till she got past us—the schooner's stem would shut out the ap
pearance of the eddy, all the way above it.

Q. Then, in your judgment, from the effect the eddy had on the skiff, could the accident have been avoided by the commander of the steamer? A. I think the accident was all occasioned by the eddy—if the boat had not turned round towards the steamer, I think she would have cleared it—the eddy was the occasion of turning it round—I do not think the master of the steamer could have avoided the accident—he could not have per
ceived the eddy until he came past us—I did not observe the helmsman starboard the helm when the small boat was seen—I could not see any negligence or carelessness on the part of the captain—I am in no way in
terested in steam-boats—they are as much injury to me as they are to any person—if the small boat was coming in the direction that has been stated, the effect of the eddy would be to catch her head, and cant her round, and saw that

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You say you think the master of the steamer could not have avoided it? A. Not from the time of my seeing it—they were that close together when I saw them, that he could not have avoided it—I should think they were not more than the length of the boat apart—I think there was—not then sufficient time to back the steamer—if she had been coming at the rate of but five or six miles an hour, I do not think it could have been avoided, they were too close together when I saw them—they were almost in the act of striking—there is, perhaps, about 200 fathoms' breadth between the Tunnel-pier and the tier of vessels on the other side of the river, but the steamer was coming to the pier where she was going to land her passengers.
JURY. Q. Would the eddy have any effect on vessels seventy or eighty feet from yours? A. Yes—straight upwards, but not outside—the tide is very strong at spring-tides.
COURT. Q. Was the eddy anything extraordinary, or is it a thing

which commonly happens when a vessel is stuck out into the tide and across it? A. Yes, it commonly happens—a person accustomed to the river, on seeing a schooner there, would know that there must be an eddy, if they saw the vessel was aground, if they took notice of it.

RICHARD FIELD . I am a waterman, employed by the Tunnel-pier Com
pany at the Lower Tunnel-pier. On the 25th of Oct. I saw the Waterman, No. 6, coming up before ten o'clock in the morning—I saw a skiff with persons in it—it was about forty or fifty yards from the steamer when I first saw it—I saw some man in the boat, get up and wave his hand to the steamer.

Q. From the position of the steamer and the skiff at that time, could the steamer, in your opinion, have avoided it? A. Yes, if he had altered his helm, by starboarding the helm, or stopping the engine, might have saved it—there was nothing to prevent them taking a left-hand course—I saw a man on the paddle-box—if he had been looking out he must have seen the boat—he sung out to them, "Hoy, hoy"—he did not stop the steamer at all—he kept on his course—I saw an eddy from the schooner that was lying aground—that eddy could not have affected the skiff at all—she was away from it—she was in the tide's way—if she had been in the eddy, the steamer could not have got at her at all.

Cross-examined by. MR. CLARKSON. Q. What are you at the Lower Tunnel-pier? A. A waterman—I act for the Company—I am on duty there—these boats go to the Upper Tunnel-pier—when a steamer is going with the tide, by merely stopping her engine, and not turning it astern, she would go a long distance before she stopped still—perhaps she would go half a mile before she would stop by herself, so as to have only tide-way upon her, unless she was stopped by the engine being reversed—they could stop her by reversing the engine in her own length, that is my judg
ment—the length of the Waterman, No. 6, is eighty or ninety feet—if she was going at eight or nine knots, and the engine were reversed, I think she might be brought up in that distance—our steam-boats go at the rate of eight or ten miles an hour on the river.

Q. It is a rival company, is it? A. Yes; they are in conjunction now—they go to different piers—there is no opposition now—the two com
panies have agreed together.

JURY. Q. Were the companies in conjunction at the time of the acci
dent? A. I think they were.

COURT. Q. Do you mean that these steamers go at ten miles an hour in the Pool? A. Yes; a steamer obeys the helm the better the quicker she is going—if she was only going with the tide she would not obey it at all.
Witnesses for the Defence.

ROBERT WILSON . I am a waterman. On Friday, the 25th of Oct., I was on the Thames in a wherry, a regular waterman's boat—I was coming from the Wapping Dock-stairs adjoining the Tunnel, about a quarter or twenty minutes before ten o'clock in the morning—I noticed a schooner aground against the Lower Tunnel-pier—that schooner created a great deal of eddy, and a very dangerous one, by lying across the tide—I was caught in the eddy, and it threw me out on a different course to what I wanted to go, and I bad to recover myself to go on my course—I regained my course, and landed my passengers—I returned in about ten minutes, and on my

return I was drawn by the eddy of this vessel up against the stern of the vessel with great violence—there was no one in my boat then—I was thrown out of my course both in going and returning—I knew of the eddy before I got into it.

MR. WILDE. Q. How long have you been a waterman? A. Very nearly thirty years—the effect of the eddy was to draw me up against the schooner—till I got clear of her stern, it would hug me to the vessel, but then the race of the tide would drive me from her—I was going from Wapping Dock-stairs across the river.

COURT. Q. Then, till you got beyond the end of the schooner you were protected from the tide running up, in some degree by the pier and schooner? A. Yes, by the eddy—the schooner was between me and the main run of the tide—when I got beyond the eddy the tide turned my head out—I had three passengers at first—neither of them are here—it had more effect on the boat then, but it acted differently as we were going a different way—the heavier the boat, the more power the eddy would have upon it—she would be deeper in the water, and the eddy runs quicker under the water than on the surface.
SIR JOHN BAYLEY . Q. When you were leaving Wapping Dock-stairs, the effect of the eddy was to throw your boat's head out into the river? A. Yes; and as I returned it drew me up against the vessel.

THOMAS JONES . I am a waterman lighterman. On Friday, the 25th of Oct., I was navigating a barge on the river—I was going to stop it at the Upper Tunnel-pier—I was going up with the tide—I saw a schooner aground against the Lower Tunnel-pier, which I belong to—that schooner caused an eddy, about twice the vessel's length, round her—it was up and down the river too—it caused a circular eddy—it ran right round, astern of the vessel in particular—she laid athwart the river—the eddy extended a good way out, about two barges' length from her into the river—my barge got into the eddy, and it stopped me from going to the place where I intended, the Upper Tunnel-pier—it turned her round twice—when I found she was in the eddy I let her go her own road, and put my oar in, finding it was no use—I began to feel the eddy soon after I came to the schooner, almost directly I came opposite her.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. The eddy was merely die course of the tide being obstructed? A. By the schooner—the eddy would certainly extend more than many inches beyond the extreme point of the vessel—the vessel lying aground on the causeway, stops the tide flowing its original course, and throws it right away—I saw nothing of the accident—it was about twenty minutes before ten o'clock when I came up to the schooner—the Pool was middling clear at that time—if I had not been caught by the eddy, my barge would not have been turned round—I was not in the mid
stream—I was about two barges' length from the schooner, and was going to stop at the Upper Tunnel-pier—I could not get to the Tunnel pier without going through the eddy.

WILLIAM MASON . I am collector for the Chartered Gas Company. On the morning of the 25th of Oct. I was standing on the Upper Tunnel pier, and saw the schooner aground, alongside the Lower Tunnel pier—I saw a skiff coming from the opposite shore, and saw the Waterman steamer—there was a very strong eddy below the pier I was standing on—I saw the skiff in the eddy, it turned her round—I am speaking of the skiff that was

afterwards upset—it was the only one that was there at the time, I believe—the eddy threw the skiff's head out—I saw the accident happen—I did not hear any orders given on board the steamer, and did not see anything done by the persons on board.

COURT. Q. Did you see whether the steamer changed her course or not? A. I did not—I saw the skiff, as she came round the stern of the steamer, which was more than 300 yards from where I stood—I did not notice whether the steamer changed her course or not.

JURY. Q. Did you keep your eye on the steam-vessel all the time? A. I saw the boat, as I was walking backwards and forwards—I did not lose sight of the steamer at all—if she had altered her course materially I should have seen it—a little deviation, perhaps, I might not have noticed—I kept my eye on her—I know she did not deviate twenty feet from her course, but if she did five or ten it might not have been noticed by me—she did not change her course anything to speak of—I observed that she did not change her course.

SIR JOHN BAYLEY . Q. Did you notice that her paddles were stopped? A. Yes, just previous to the accident—half a second before—it was a momentary thing, just previous to her striking, just after she had cleared the stern of the schooner—I did not hear anybody hail on board, or any orders given—after the skiff was struck, ropes, and everything that was available, were thrown from the steamer, and every assistance rendered.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did the steamer stop and try to pick the men up? A. The men were floated out into the stream—the steamer did stop for ten minutes—I cannot say it was stationary for ten minutes, but the engine was stopped—I did not see one of the persons that were upset en
deavouring to reach the steam-boat—he was outside—they threw over part of the sails and ropes from the steamer—they had no boat—I know nothing more of the steamer than being a passenger in her frequently—not in that particular boat, but in any of the steam-boats—I saw the skiff turned round by the eddy, just when the steam-boat was turning round the stern of the schooner.

COURT. Q. How came the steamer to stop for ten minutes, what was she doing during that time? A. She was coming to the pier for passengers, and she stopped on the accident taking place—I was waiting for her—she just glided to the pier—I got on board—she did not go on immediately with her passengers—I cannot say as to the time, as there was confusion—I should say it was about ten minutes—I observed that all the persons were thrown out of the skiff—I cannot say how many there were—they were picked up before the steamer went off—all that could be found at the time—I do not know how many were picked up—I was told they were all picked up—I was on board the steamer—we went on understanding all were picked up—that was my impression at the time.

RICHARD WHEELER . I was master of the Orana steam-boat, running to Ipswich—I was a passenger on board the Waterman No. 6 steamer, on Friday morning, the 25th Oct.—I saw a schooner lying aground by the Lower Tunnel pier—I saw a skiff after we passed the schooner—I did not see it before because my attention was not called to it—I cannot ex
actly say what distance she was from the steam-boat as we passed the schooner, it was so momentary—she was not above her own length and a half from the steam-vessel—my attention was called to her by the master calling out to ease the vessel, as soon as we got abreast of the stern of the

schooner—that order was instantly obeyed—the schooner occasioned a very great eddy—the skiff was in the eddy, and seemed unmanageable altogether with it—if I had been in command of the Waterman myself, in my judgment I could not have avoided the accident, nor could any other man on the river.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. If you had been in command, and on the paddle box of the vessel, should you have kept a good look out? A. Yes—I think I should be able to see a boat if it was crossing the river, if it was about 150 feet before me—it would be my duty to keep at the same speed as before, if the boat was across my bows—would not run right into the boat of course—I could prevent that by easing and stopping the vessel—I should consider it my duty to do so.

Q. If you were in command should you think it your duty to go at the rate of ten miles an hour round a place without knowing what was be
hind it? A. Yes—I should not think it necessary to lessen the speed, although I could not see what was behind the place we were going round.

JURY. Q. Will you stake your knowledge of your business, and your own character, that you would not stop your vessel in going round such a place? A. Very often in places we are obliged to go in that way, to get the vessel out of a little bother.

COURT. Q. Was there a little bother on this occasion? A. Well, I did not observe that—very often we have to shove ahead at the rate of ten miles an hour to prevent an accident—I did not observe whether there was any such occasion here—I am not aware that it would have been proper on this particular occasion to have gone slower round the Point.

MR. BALLANTINE. Were you on the look-out? A. No, I was only a passenger; it was, of course, the business of the man on the paddle-box to look out and see whether there was a boat ahead—very likely he had an opportunity of seeing the boat before I did; of course he had, because he was higher than I was—he would have an opportunity of seeing it as soon as we cleared the end of the schooner—that might have been two seconds before I saw her—at the time he called out, "Ease her," I looked ahead and saw the danger—we were just past the schooner's stern when he called out, "Ease her"—he could not see her before that, that I am aware of—he saw her as soon as he could—she was a boat's length and a half from the vessel when I saw her—I saw her the moment he called out, and I believe he called out the moment he could see her—I do not know when he saw her—he saw her before I saw her, at least he called out to ease the vessel, I could not tell when he could see her; I was not ob
serving, and did not see the boat till he called out to ease her—the thing that prevented him from seeing was the stern of the schooner—we were in the act of passing the stern of the schooner when he called out, "Ease her"—I do not know whether that was the first time he could see her—his attention might have been called to her—I did not see her till he called, "Ease her."

COURT. Q. The schooner hindered him from seeing the skiff for some time? A. Yes—it ceased to hinder him at some time—I cannot say how soon it was after it ceased to hinder him from seeing the boat that he called out—we were just passing the end of the schooner as he called out, "Ease her."

SIR J. BAYLEY. Q. If you had seen the skiff on your larboard
bow, it would have been your duty to have eased her? A. Of course—if
she was across our bows we should not ease her at all—there would not be the same necessity to ease her when she had crossed our bows and got on our starboard bow.

THOMAS JOYCE . I am a leather-dresser. I was a passenger on board the Waterman steamer on this day. I was on the cabin stairs at the time the accident happened—I did not see the blow struck, but I heard and felt it—before I felt the blow the engines were positively stopped—there were several passengers on deck—it was rather a wet morning, and many were down in the cabin.

THOMAS LILLY . I am a waterman. I was a passenger on board the Waterman steamer on the 25th of Oct.—I saw the schooner aground by the Lower Tunnel-pier—I was standing on the starboard side of the pad
dle-box, just before it—I saw the skiff, I should suppose, about half a minute before we rounded the schooner's stern—as soon as I saw the skiff, I heard the orders, "Ease her," "Stop her," and "Turn her astern," given by the master—those orders were given in succession; I suppose, in half a second, as soon as he could repeat them—the skiff was in the eddy when I saw her—the eddy had a great effect on her—nobody has the power of pulling in a boat when it gets into an eddy—she was quite un
manageable—she was turned round towards the steamer, not exactly round—in my judgment, the eddy, and nothing else, caused the collision—I can give no other account—had no schooner been there, and nothing to cause the eddy, the boat would have gone into the stairs before the steamer found her.

COURT. Q. Were you very much astonished when you saw the eddy? A. No, not at all, because I was certain that the schooner lying aground would cause an eddy—I knew there must be an eddy before I saw it.

RALPH SCOTT . I am a waterman's apprentice. On the morning of the 25th of Oct. I was on the Upper Tunnel-pier, and saw the accident—I did not see anything done by the steamer in order to avoid it—the accident would not have occurred if the schooner had not been where she was—she created an eddy—in my judgment the skiff could not have been seen by the steamer before she rounded the schooner.

COURT. Q. The captain of the steamer would see the schooner there, would he not? A. Yes—the eddy drew the boat's head down, and threw it out into the tide again—if the captain had seen the boat a hundred yards before he came to her, and had stopped the engine, or turned the helm starboard, that would have prevented the accident.

SAMUEL BRISTOW . I am mate on board the Waterman steamer, No. 6. I was on board on the 25th of Oct.—I saw the skiff when I was abreast of the schooner's stern—the first thing I did was to hail the skiff.
COURT. Q. Whereabouts were you? A. I was on the fore starboard deck—the prisoner was on the paddle-box—it was his business to look out—he was the person who was directing the motions of the vessel.

SIR J. BAYLEY. Q. What did you hail the skiff to do? A. To keep clear of us—she would have done so had it not been for the eddy—I can
not say how near she was to us then—I should say within something less than fifty or sixty yards when I first saw her, thereabouts—I cannot say exactly—it might be about two of our vessel's length—I cannot say exactly—I dare say our vessel is ninety feet long—I did not hear any orders given by the captain when I first hailed her—I believe I hailed her first—when I saw her in the eddy coming towards us, I heard the captain say, "Ease

her, stop her"—I believe those orders were obeyed—I ran to pick up a boat-hook for the purpose of defending the boat off if she came nigh us, which she did—I saw the boat fly out into the eddy, and then ran, and picked up the boat-hook—I could not keep her off—I was there in time to do so, but the boat rowing towards us, and coming out in the eddy rapidly, and our boat keeping way at the time, I had no power to keep her off.

Q. Did you hear any orders given about altering your course? A. The word "Starboard" was given—I believe that was before the words "Ease I her, stop her"—I believe the man at the helm put the helm a starboard by the course I saw her come—I was not looking out, I was looking at the boat at the time, but judging from the head of the boat, and the way she went, I judged the helm must have been starboarded, otherwise her head would not have come out from the shore as it did—the boat would have gone under the wheel before, had it not been for the man pulling with one hand and stopping the other—that was a proper direction to give in order to avoid a collision.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long have you been on board the Water
man? A. About a year and nine months.

Q. Supposing you were fifty yards from an object perfectly stationary, and you going at full speed, should you be able to stop your vessel before coming up to that object? A. You may easily stop the engine, but the vessel would not stop in the time—the engine might be stopped—if we were fifty yards from an object, and going with the tide, we could not prevent our steamer from going over that object—if we backed our engines, and starboarded our helm, that would not avoid it with the tide in our favour—we had a man at the helm—if the object, instead of lying still, were making to the right, we should be able to avoid it by starboarding our helm, which would throw our head away—that would, take very little time—the boat came to us faster than our helm would act.

COURT. Q. You say he called out, "Starboard" just before "Ease her, stop her? A. Yes, we were then so close to the boat that by the time I got up the boat-hook she was striking against us, at the time the helm was starboarded the boat was about her own length from us, about twenty-three feet—the object of starboarding the helm was to clear the boat if possible—if that had been done when we were fifty yards off, we might have got further out of her way, her head could have been thrown more off.

Q. Then, if at the time when you hailed the boat, when she was unman
ageable, your helm had been starboarded, your vessel would have cleared her? A. The boat was not unmanageable at the time I first saw her—she was rowing down fair in the tide—she was not in the eddy when I first saw her—I do not think we should have got clear of her if our helm had been starboarded at the time I hailed her.

Q. Then you tried to do that at twenty feet which would be impossible in fifty yards? A. If it had not been so we should have struck the boat in the other bow, by backing we threw her head rather more in shore, whereas we should have struck her on the other bow had it not been so—I believe I was the first person that called out—I did not notice that the prisoner called out or took any notice of her—the first I heard him say was, "Starboard the helm"—that was too late, because the eddy had then taken the boat's head—if there had been nothing but the true tide she would have cleared us, had we been going as fast as we could pos
sibly
go—it was the fault of the eddy entirely—I was aware there would be an eddy when I saw the schooner aground.

JAMES KERR . I am a waterman—I was on board the Waterman steamer on the 25th of Oct., and was at the wheel—after we pasted the schooner, which was aground alongside Lower Tunnel-pier, the captain gave me orders to put the helm a-starboard—I was in the act of doing so at the time we passed the schooner—it was before we passed the schooner that he gave me the order—I knocked the helm hard a-starboard with the stool.
COURT. Q. Was that in order to pass the schooner? A. Yes—it was the usual order at that place, in order to pass the pier-head to go in to the stairs.

SIR J. BAYLEY. Q. In your way up from Woolwich had you called at Greenwich? A. Yes, we kept the Surrey shore part of the way up from Greenwich, till we bad directions to go to Limehouse-pier at Limehouse-hole—we came out from Limehouse, and made a direction as clear at we could come up the river as far as the Tunnel-pier—I remember the colli
sion taking place.

Q. Did you receive any orders what to do with the helm previous to that? A.
