After the weigh of the boat was off, I had orders from the captain, and I put the helm according to which was the right way for it to be put, in order to put her into the Tunnel-pier—after this wherry was stopped I shifted the helm—I did not feel the knock against the wherry—I did not see the collision, and did not feel it exactly—I heard it mentioned that we had run a boat down—no order was given me just before that, further than to put the helm hard a-starboard—that was an order given to get out of the way of the boat, and, as usual, to get into the pier.

COURT. Q. Then it so happened that at the time you wanted to get out of the way of the boat, you wanted to get in to the pier? A. Yes, that is the usual course when we are going to the Upper Tunnel-pier—we go in towards the Lower Tunnel-pier, and put the helm hard a-starboard, and shoot in alongside the Upper Tunnel-pier—after the order was given, I blocked the helm hard a-starboard, and ran to the starboard quarter—I threw a stern rope to the assistance of the persons that were overboard, and I lent a gentleman a hand to get a stool to chuck overboard, to restore the people's lives.

GEORGE THORNTON . I was the engineer on board the Waterman No. 6, on the 25th of Oct., when this accident happened. I had been on deck previous to arriving at Lower Tunnel-pier—I went below, and in quite two minutes after I got below I received the orders, "Ease her, stop her, turn her astern"—as well as I can judge, we were about the Lower Tunnel-pier at that time—those orders were given rapidly, almost as quick as they could be given—I obeyed those orders.

WILLIAM SALVAGE . I am a clerk in Somerset-house. I was a pas
senger on board the Waterman steamer on the 25th of Oct.—I saw a schooner lying athwart the tide, between the two Tannel piers—shortly after, I heard the captain cry out in one breath, "Ease her, stop her, turn her astern"—I got on to the gangway, and saw a skiff, with five or six men in her—she shot out, and came in contact with the fore part of the right hand paddle-box of the steamer—the boat was upset, and the persons all immersed in the water—in my judgment the accident decidedly could not have been avoided.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How old are you? A. Between seventeen and eighteen—I have had very little experience in steam navigation, or the management of steam-boats—I have never been captain, mate, or engineer—I have very little experience.
COURT. Q. What is your line? A. Clerk in the Registry-office—I have been there six months—I was with my father before that—I had just left school.
SIR J, BAYLEY . Q. Do you live at Plumstead, in Kent? A. Yea—that is about a mile and a half from the river—I have been in the habit of going up and down every day, for the last six months.

(Captain Ralph, formerly in the Hon. East India Company's service, and Sir Jamei Gordon, Lieutenant Governor of Greenwich Hospital, gave the prisoner a good character as a careful, steady, and skilful man.)

GUILTY.—Strongly and earnestly recommended to mercy on account of his previous good character.
—
Confined Four Months .
Before Mr. Justice Maule.

182.
HENRY BRENTON was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
Mary Tremlett Turner Brenton. He was also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the like manslaughter.
MR. HAKE conducted the Prosecution.

HENRY WILLIS LAYER , I am a surgeon, and live at 38, Stamford-street, Lambeth. I knew Mrs. Brenton, the deceased—I was called to attend her about the 17th of Aug., and I attended her in the delivery of female child on the 20th of Aug.—she left her bed after that at about the ordinary period—she had a very good time—it was quite a natural labour—I believe it was not her first child, but I never attended her before—after leaving her bed she was attacked with rheumatism—I think she left her bed about the third week, or probably rather before—I do not know how long after leaving her bed she returned to it—I think several days, but I was not there all the time—I merely called in occasionally to see how she was, after being attacked with rheumatism—my attendance then recommenced—she was then keeping her bed—I left town on the 25th of Sept. I think, and left the case in charge of Mr. Saunders—I returned on the 10th of Oct., and on that evening I saw the deceased with her father, whom I was then introduced to, and Mr. Saunders—she was then in a state of almost insensibility—she was paralyzed in the right arm, and the left leg appeared paralyzed—she had spasms of the muscles of the jaw, producing what is commonly called locked-jaw—she had a very low feeble pulse—she could only be aroused to answer a question or two, not a sequence of questions—I was shown a wound which was then sloughing on her back—it was about two inches long and one wide—it was a slough in the centre with a red margin, and shading off to the natural colour of the skin—it was on the sacrum, over the lower bone of the back, not quite the lowest—Mr. Brenton returned with roe to my house for medicine, and he said, seeing I was returned, and being his wife's medical attendant, he thought it right to state to me what had occurred on that particular even
ing in question, that he was desirous of having intercourse with his wife, which she resisted, and thinking it arose from ill temper, or words to that effect, he had persisted, and was exceedingly sorry for the results—I think he remarked that he thought it rather extraordinary the bruise on the back

had not been discovered by the medical men on their first attendance after the 3rd—I am not certain whether it was at that period, or on any future occasion, that that occurred—Mrs. Brenton died on the 19th of Oct.—I was not present at her death—she was dead when I called that day—I made a post mortem examination on the morning of the inquest, the Monday following, and the day previous—it occupied many hours—we took a portion one day, and a portion the next—Mr. Saunders was pre
sent with me on the first day, and Mr. Fisher, Mr. Saunders, and myself on the second day, the day of the inquest—the father of the deceased was not present—I believe he was in the house a portion of the time, but not in the room—(referring to his minutes)—I first opened' the skull—on removing the skull, I saw nothing of any importance on the outer surface of the brain—there was an effusion of about two ounces and a half of serum in the arachnoid sac, which is one of the cavities of the brain—that was more than the ordinary quantity—there were no external marks of injury on the head—the vessels of the brain were in a turgid state, more particularly on the left side, where there was a slight degree of adhesion of the membranes of the brain—there was about two drachms of serum in the ventricle—that was not material—that was all I saw the first day—on the second day's examination, I saw external marks of sloughing over the sacrum, which I have spoken of as having seen when she was alive—the vessels of the spinal cord, or the marrow, were congested, having patches of red on the top—there were coagula of blood at different portions of the spine, that extended, in different places, from the last dorsal to the cervical ver
tebree, that is, from the bone of the back to the bone of the neck—then were two dark marks under each knee—the spinal marrow was in a state of inflammation—the symptoms I have mentioned would indicate that inflam
mation, mation, and others, which showed themselves previously to death, tender
ness ness progressing up the spine, and pain, evidenced by flinching on pres
sure, up the spine externally—I first discovered that tenderness at the sacrum, and some portion of the os nominata, the bones which form the inside of the hip, or the smaller bones of the pelvis—it extended then up to the first dorsal bone of the back—on further examination I found that it extended further up the dorsal—the sacrum bone was exceedingly tender, so that she could not bear pressure on it, and flinched whenever it was touched—inflammation was the cause of that tenderness—the bone was also enlarged—I attribute that, also, to the inflammation—after death I found that the surface of the bone, immediately under the slough, was dark, as if it had lost its vitality, as if it had been mortified during life—there was a degree of cares, or softening of the bone immediately under it—that state of the bone was decidedly connected with the wound that I had observed externally—they acknowledged the same cause—I attribute the death to inflammation, or irritation of the spinal cord—I presume when it extended as far as the origin of the phrenic nerve, the nerve by which we breathe that that was the immediate cause of death—there had evidently been pressure on the spinal marrow from the coagula which was formed there—when the phrenic nerve is affected, life will very soon become extinct—if the phrenic nerve was paralyzed it would cease to act on the diaphragm, and then the diaphragm losing its power, instant death would happen—I suppose that was the cause of death.
Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Had you attended this poor lady long previous to her death? A. From about the 17th of August—that

was the first time I had ever seen her—I think she was of a delicate con
stitution—on my return to town she was labouring under a shock of the nervous system—the system generally had received a shock—I do not think such a state would exist if a person died from an attack of apoplexy—I should say locked jaw is certainly not very often produced by an at
tack of apoplexy—apoplexy may be accompanied by paralysis of the arm—apoplexy produces a depression, a loss of power of the nervous system—I think I never attended a person who died from concussion of the brain.

Q. Could you tell what would be the difference between a person dying from apoplexy and from concussion of the brain? A. I think, if I attended from an early period, I could, no doubt, form an opinion—the appearances of the deceased's head did not indicate sufficient symptoms of apoplexy—the great mischief here was in the spine, and my previous knowledge of the case made me suppose so the more—I saw nothing in the head to produce apoplexy—when I observed the wound on the spine I did not attribute it to the effect of disease—not at any time.

ELIZABETH LEE . I am a nurse—I attended Mrs. Brenton from the 19th of Aug. up to the time of her death—I remember the night of the 3rd of Oct.—I left Mrs. Brenton at eleven o'clock that night—I left Mr. Brenton in the bedroom with her—I went into the front parlour—they were in the back parlour—I slept in the front parlour that night—after I had been there ten minutes I heard Mrs. Brenton say, "You may pinch me, or take pieces out of me, but I will die before I will give in to you"—I heard a scuffling first of all, and that expression directly, at the tame time—the scuffling continued about an hour, from eleven till twelve—I did not hear Mr. Brenton say anything—I heard no other remark from Mrs. Brenton in that hour—they were quiet for a little while, and then I heard them begin again—that was about a quarter after twelve—I heard her call him, "You wretch," and "a beast"—she said, if she had had Cobley, he would not hare used her in that way—I heard nothing else—that was the last I heard—I heard no sounds or any groaning, that I swear—I have never stated so—the baby, six weeks old, was in the room—it was crying in the course of the night, two or three times, and I heard Mr. Brenton speak to it, and hushing it—he was crying "Hush"—about half-past six or seven in the morning I knocked at their door—Mr. Brenton told me to come in—I leant over and took the baby out of the bed—Mr. Brenton was in bed at the time—I saw Mrs. Brenton—I asked her what was the matter, but received no answer—she was in an insensible state, but I had seen her so several times—after this I left the room, and went into the front room with the, child—I prepared the breakfast at eight o'clock, and took it in—Mrs. Brenton did not get up to eat any—she was not well enough to take any—Mr. Brenton got up about a quarter to eight, and went into the front parlour, and took breakfast at the same table with me—I did not put any question to him about Mrs. Brenton—I did not say a word to him about what I had heard—I am married—I attended Mrs. Brenton all this time—she was in a very weak, debilitated state, and had been so during the eighteen months I had at
tended her—Mr. Brenton went out about nine that morning—I told Mrs. Baker, the landlady, what had taken place, as soon as he had gone out—it might be twenty minutes after he was gone, I cannot say exactly—Mrs. Baker did not send for a medical man on seeing her—she did not do any
thing—we had a medical man, who always came, every day, about twelve o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What was the nature of this scuffling, in your opinion? A. I think he wished to cohabit with his wife—that appeared to be his endeavour—she never complained of any blow being struck—there was no cry out, nor anything that could lead me to believe any blow had been struck—she seemed to be struggling, and not to be inclined to allow him—she was an obstinate temper, and I could tell she refused his purpose, and he was endeavouring to effect it—this was six weeks after her confinement—I attended her once before when she miscarried—the prisoner is twenty-two years of age—she was always ailing ever since I have known her—he has been a most excellent husband to her as ever lived—I do not think a better man ever lived—I know what a✗ good husband is—I have got a very bad one myself—I go out at a✗ monthly nurse—the prisoner always behaved with kindness to hit wife, and waited on her—at one period he was in very comfortable circum
stances—after his marriage his circumstances somewhat declined—when I first went there, till the last two months, during her confinement, she had two feather-beds on her bed, six pillows, two bolsters, and about seves blankets, not on the bed, but under it, and when she was confined she had a hard flock bed and flock mattress, which, she said, frequently made her bones sore—the things were pledged, as they were not so well off—it was in consequence of their reduced circumstances—they had been pledged to procure necessaries for himself and wife—for her comforts, of course, as well as his own—he was too fond of his wife, I am sorry to say, a woman that drank so—a Dr. Fisher came to see her—at the time he came she was not sensible—she was never sensible, during the sixteen days, from the morn
ing it happened till she died—I was with her when she died—her husband always behaved kindly to her, as kind as a man could be—at the time she miscarried she was in a state of insensibility very much resembling this state, and the landlady, who is outside, can say the same.

MR. HAKE. Q. Have you seen Mr. Brenton since he has been in custody? A. No, only at Union-hall—I had no conversation with him there—Mr. Brenton was an excellent husband to his wife ever since I knew them—I recollect Mrs. Brenton having a black eye, but it wai not given her by Mr. Brenton, it was by being intoxicated, and that very day I fetched her seven quarterns of gin, and then, before Mr. Brenton came home, I fetched a jug of hot water to bring it up again—she got the black eye by falling down the stairs—he never struck her in his life in my pre
sence—on the 3rd of Oct. Mrs. Brenton had made no complaint to me of any sore on the lower part of her back.

COURT. Q. How long did you remain nursing her on this last occa
sion? sion? A. Eight weeks—the whole time from her delivery to her death—I slept in the front parlour—Mr. Brenton was away during six weeks—the first month he was away—he came home for a day or two, and then went away for another fortnight.

JURY. Q. Was the mattress on the floor, or on a bedstead? A. On a French bedstead—there were laths underneath—it was a very thin mat
tress—the flock bed was taken away by order of the doctors, and shelaid on the bare mattress—the doctor said it would be better.

COURT. Q. He went away for a month, beginning from the time of her delivery? A. Yes—he was gone three or four days, or a week before her delivery—I cannot exactly say the day he went—he returned in a month and two days—he then slept with his wife—she had been up once

or twice in that time, but not more—he then went away again, and re
turned in a fortnight—he then slept with Mrs. Brenton—this happened within a day or two after the six weeks—the first night he came home after the month, she wished me to go home and sleep, because Mr. Brenton was coming to sleep with her—I did not sleep in the parlour that time—there are very thin folding-doors between the parlours—she was always ailing—at the time Mr. Brenton came home at the end of the month I asked her whether she was in a fit state for him to sleep with her, and she said the was as well as she ever was in her life—I went to her mother's to sleep for three nights before this happened, as she wished me—the first and only night I slept in the front parlour, when Mr. Brenton was sleeping in the back parlour with his wife, was the night this happened—he had been home some nights before, sleeping with her, and I was away from the par
lour lour on those nights, because Mrs. Brenton desired me—she told me her hus
band was coming to sleep with her, as she had said before—I did not speak to her about her weak state then—I thought there was no, occasion—she got the black eye by tumbling down when intoxicated—she got so very often during the whole time I knew her, except when she was confined—I do not suppose she ever went a day without having six or seven quarterns unknown to her husband, end when I would not fetch it, she would send her little girl, nine years old, and when she was not at home she would send the potboy—that was not while she was at Mrs. Baker's—she had not been at Mrs. Baker's above three weeks before she was confined—she did not get drunk while she was at Mrs. Baker's—she left it off when she was confined—there was nothing in the scuffling I heard which induced me to suppose any violence was used—it was nothing more than might take place between husband and wife—I did not like to interpose as I was not called—had I heard any blow given, or anything of that kind, I should have gone in directly, but I did not—the first place at which she was liv
ing, where she used to get drunk, was at No. 18, Woodbridge-street, Clerkenwell, and the next was No. 24, Windsor-terrace, City-road.

JOHN HOUSTON . I am a member of the Royal College of Surgeons—I have practised as a surgeon for forty years—I am the father of the de
ceased—her name was Mary Tremlett Turner Brenton—I think she was thirty-three years old when she died—I cannot speak positively—she was a person of very sober habits—I can speak to that up to the time of her death—I knew her when she was in Woodbridge-street—I visited her. fre
quently there—I did not visit her in Windsor-terrace—I believe she was there but a very short time—I did not see her there at all—I never saw her intoxicated in my life, from infancy up to the present moment, I do not believe she was ever intoxicated for a single moment—I believe it is a foul calumny, a perjury—I never saw the slightest thing of the kind, nor was she ever the worse for liquor, though I visited her constantly, nor did I ever know of the charge till I heard it brought so vilely in this Court—I never saw her at all the worse for liquor in the whole course of her life—I saw her about ten days before the 3rd of Oct.—she was in a very emaci
ated and debilitated state, so much so that I was obliged to assist her in getting up in the bed—on Friday, the 4th of Oct., I received a message stating that my daughter was dying, and that she had been supposed to have had some poison given her—I examined her on that occasion—I found there was concussion of the brain, para
lysis of the right arm, and a locked jaw—I saw Mr. Saunders, the sur
geon,

in the evening—I was there at eight o'clock—I understood he was coming to see her that night—she was treated for concussion of the brain that night—this was on Friday—nothing particular occurred until the fol
lowing Monday but a progress of the diseased action—I saw her twice every day during the whole of her illness—on Monday I found that there was a morbid action of the bladder and rectum, a paralysis of the two muscles which contain the matter of those parts; and on seeing her endea
vouring to move her leg, I found there was a particular contraction of the left leg, so that she could not turn it over—it was a morbid action—I could not account on the first day for the locked jaw, because that arises from a different cause to concussion of the brain; but when I saw that same action of the leg, I then concluded that there was something the matter with the back—I mentioned that, and I heard the prisoner, on hearing me do so, desire the nurse to tell me that she had a sloughing in the back—I then had her turned over, and examined the back, and there I saw a morbid action about the size of a crown-piece, or not so large pro
bably, perhaps about as large as half-a-crown—there was a vesicle, and the morbid action of sloughing was going on—from the appearance of the parts, and knowing that the locked jaw, in all probability, arose from some injury of a remote nerve, I concluded at once that a blow had been in
flicted on that part, the left leg and thigh being in the same morbid state as the locked jaw; and I beg to observe, that a paralysis of the bladder and rectum always accompanies an injury to the spinal marrow at that part of the back—it was on the lower part of the back, on the sacrum—that is a part of the lumbar region—a concussion cannot take place without a blow—I have seen many concussions of the spine, but I never saw one without a blow—the very term itself signifies that—it is a shock—a concussion necessarily implies external force.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long was your daugh
ter living in Woodbridge-street? A. I think for three months—I think I was there seven times during that period—I did not see her at all at Windsor-terrace—I saw her at the house where she died once, ten days before the 3rd of Oct., but I saw her several times while she was there, because she called upon me frequently, and I had opportunities of seeing her—fifty times—I always gave her money whenever she applied for it—I think three weeks before her confinement she called on me, and I gave her 5s—I attended at the inquest—I was not turned out of the room by order of the Coroner—I was requested to go out of the room, in consequence of being under very excited feelings—I was in the room where they were dis
secting my child, and I was not in a sound state of mind—I could not bear my own existence, and I was requested to go out by the Coroner—I beg to say that the bed was ordered to be removed, in consequence of its being in such a filthy state, from the contents of the bladder, that she could not lie on it, and from no other motive.

THOMAS JONES SAUNDERS . I attended Mrs. Brenton, in place of Mr. Laver, when he was out of town—I saw her on the 3rd of Oct.—she was better on that day, and I recommended her to leave her bed—I do not re
collect whether she expressed any intention of doing so—she made no complaint to me on that day of any bruise or wound on her person—I called professionally, about one o'clock, on the 4th of Oct.—she was then lying in bed, in a state of insensibility—I had been partly informed by the landlady that there was a probability of her having taken laudanum—Mr.

Brenton was not at home, and the nurse was not there—I had not sufficient information, in a medical way, as to what had occurred to bring Mrs. Brenton into that state, for me to act upon—I called again about seven or eight o'clock in the evening—I then met Mr. Houston—we did not exa
mine her body then—she was very pale, in a state of collapse, the pulse rather small, and the pupils of the eyes not acting—there were symptoms of some shock to the nervous system, and upon that I acted—I saw her again early next morning (Saturday)—I saw her on the Monday—the wound was not pointed out to me till the Tuesday—it was a dark, disco
loured surface of skin, with a vesicle or blister upon it, but not a decided wound—I attended the case for seven or eight days altogether—I saw her occasionally after Mr. Laver's return, but not regularly—the wound was on the sacrum—there was tenderness of the sacrum, the result of inflammation, and a redness from the wound—it appeared a wound of recent origin—I should have thought it had existed two, three, or four days, possibly, pre
vious to the Tuesday, but it is uncertain to fix a time—the inflammation gradually extended up the spine—I was present at the post mortem exa
mination—the spine was then opened—we found symptoms of previous inflammation, and there was blood extravasated on the dorsal vertebree more than elsewhere, in fact, there almost alone, principally there, and up
wards towards the neck—there was congestion—the sacrum bone was rather soft—I attributed that softness to the inflammation consequent on the ex
ternal sore—the inflammation of the spine might have arisen from a blow to that part, or, in fact, to any part of the spine, or its course—Mrs. Brenton was a woman of very feeble constitution, which would decidedly make a blow take the greater effect.

Q. Now, looking to the state in which the spinal marrow was, and look
ing at the whole case before and after death, are yoa of opinion that a blow had been struck on the sacrum? A. I am of opinion that there was a certain shock to the nervous system—how produced I am not fully pre
pared to say—looking at the state of Mrs. Brenton's health on the 3rd of Oct., I think some severe struggle or conflict might produce those appear
ances—it must be a shock, a very severe injury to the head or spine—it must be a very severe conflict—striking and beating would concuss the spine, in her weak state especially.
COURT. Q. Might an accidental fall, or knocking against anything hard have produced the effects? A. That might have done it.
MR. HAKE. Q. She had never complained to you of any fall, had she? A. She had not—there were blue marks under the ham of the thigh, as if of bruises.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Small marks? A. Yes, they appeared the result of pinches—they were under the thigh, towards the knee—I saw the bed she was lying on, but did not notice it—having connection in her debilitated state might produce hysteria—it might have some effect on the nervous system—I do not say that the death re
sulted from the bruise on the sacrum—I do not know from what, but a general shock to the nervous system—I cannot form any opinion that it resulted from the bruise—I saw the body examined—there was no other bruise that could have caused the death—if it was occasioned by anything but the bruise, it must have been by some general nervous derangement—I do not know how to account for it—there might have been some shock to the system which did not leave any external trace—I cannot tell what
it might have resulted from—I have a doubt at this moment—I cannot speak positively.

MR. HAKE. Q. Was there any appearance of hysteria on the 4th, when you saw Mrs. Brenton? A. At first, perhaps, one might feel inclined to think so; but in a very short time my opinion was formed that it was not hysteria, decidedly not, from what I saw subsequently.

COURT. Q. Did you examine the viscera of the stomach? I did, it was healthy—she was a person of very weak constitution—she was of a rheumatic habit, and of a delicate habit altogether—the liver appeared to. lerably healthy—there was nothing about it to excite attention—there was nothing at all in her appearance to indicate a person in the habit of drink
ing—I ing—I did not notice it—I examined her principally with a view to ascer
tain the cause of death with relation to the wound, and the stomach.

ELIZABETH BAKER . The deceased and the prisoner were my lodgers
saw Mrs. Brenton on the 3rd of Oct., and on the 4th—she mentioned to me her intention of getting up the next morning—she appeared in better health and spirits than she had for some time—she did not complain of auy sore bones, or any sore upon her person—on the Saturday I was changing the linen with the nurse—Mrs. Houston, the deceased's mother, was there at the time (she often came to see her), and she pointed our at
tention to the bruise or wound—that was the first time it had been heard of—it appeared to me like a blow—Mrs. Brenton was not at all given to drink, as far as I know—I saw her every day—on the Thursday previous to her death she was sensible—she called me three times by my name, and asked me for some tea—I made her some—she said, "Oh, my back"—I said, "Is your back bad, dear?"—she said, "Yes, Mrs. Baker, it is; Henry kicked me"—she asked me to call for Mrs. Fisher, and she said, "O Mrs. Baker, take care of my baby"—I saw her that day when Mr. Baker was present.

THOMAS FISHER . I am a surgeon. I attended this case the greater part of the time from the 7th Oct., and was present at the post mortem examination the last day—I first saw the bruise on Mrs. Brenton's back on the second day of my seeing her, on the 8th—in my opinion it might have existed about three or four days, or it might have existed longer—I am of opinion that it was caused by violence—I have seen many wounds—I form that opinion from the symptoms combined, from the appearances previous to death and afterwards—I recollect the Saturday on which she died—she stated to me on that day that she believed she would not recover, I was questioning her—I wished to ascertain the state of her mind—her father was present—we were to meet with Mr. Laver, who did not keep his appointment—I was alone with her part of the time, and her father was with me a portion of the time—at the time she made a statement to me I was alone with her—I wished to ascertain her state with respect to her sanity, and to know whether she was sensible enough to answer my ques
tions, to ascertain in what state her health was—I asked her questions about her state of health—I asked her where she was in pain—she said, "In my back"—her father put the next question.

COURT. Q. Tell us what took place when you were alone with her. A. I asked her no more questions then when I was alone with her—after that I was again alone with her, and I asked her if she thought she should recover—she shook her head and began to cry, and said, "No"—I had asked her several questions before that—I asked where

she was in pain—she "In my back"—her father immediately came✗ in and said, "Who did it?"—nothing more took place when I was alone✗ with her the second time—nothing was said after I asked her if she thought she should recover—nothing else was said when I was alone with her, only with her father—something else was said before she shook her head and said "No," but after that, nothing was said either to me alone, or to myself and her father—I never heard her speak after that.

Q. How long was that saying "No" after anything that she said in her father's presence? A. Not a minute—he asked her something, to which she replied—he then went out, leaving her alone with me, and then I asked her if she thought she should recover—that is a very usual ques
tion for me to put to my patients, particularly when we find them in a state of insensibility, or collapse—we wish to know the state of the mind, whether they are sensible to answer any questions—I asked her that question to ascertain the state of her mind, and when she said "No" and cried, that satisfied me of the state of her mind, and I asked her no more questions—it is my common practice to put that question to persons in a weak state—I do not know whether it is of service to the patients, or whether it tends to keep up their spirits—I asked her that question to ascertain the state of her mind, to know whether she was sensible or not, in answering the questions I had put to her before with regard to the state of her health.
MR. HAKE. Q. You saw she was dying at that time, I suppose? A. No, I did not—my opinion was that she would not recover.

COURT. Q. Did you ask her whether she had slept well, about her pain, and several other questions? A. Yes—she answered some of those questions reasonably, and some she did not—I asked her where she was in pain three times over—the answer that she gave me once was, "I don't know," and the next time, "In my back"—she answered my questions so that I was in doubt as to the state of her mind—I had some doubts as to whether she was in a sound state of mind or not, and I have some doubts at the present time—I asked the last question to ascertain whether she was in a sound state of mind—she answered, "No," and cried—that answer still left me in doubt, and I cannot now tell whether she was in a sound state of mind or not—I do not know that that question more than any other had a tendency to show whether she was of sound mind or not—I did not think it an unkind or cruel question to put—perhaps it might have been, upon second consideration—I commonly speak cheerfully to my patients, but it is a very frequent question, "Well, do you think you shall recover?"—it depends upon how you express it—I do not think it shows that you think them in danger—I do not know how long this was before she died—Mr. Baker was not present at the time—I think she did expect to die, but I doubt whether she was in a sound state of mind.
NOT GUILTY .

Before
Edward Bullock, Esq.

183.
HENRY PINE was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Oct., 1 coat, value 3l.; the goods of
Frederick Bull; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Weeks .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

184.
ALFRED PRATT was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Oct., 1 bag, value 1d.; and 5 sovereigns; the property of
Samuel Groves, from his person.

SAMUEL GROVES On the 22nd of Oct., I had five sovereigns in my bag, in my right-hand pocket, at twelve o'clock in the day—it was a life. annuity I had received—I was then in a lane near the Two Brewers, at Clap. ham—I got to that public-house just before twelve—I staid there some time, and then went to a beer-shop—I came out about nine in the even
ing; and when I got half-way home, in Manor-lane, the prisoner came rustling up against me, and put his hand up my thigh—he put his hand in my pocket, which had no button, and thrust me down—he got my bag—I saw him with it—he put the money into his pocket—he shook the bag in my face, and wanted me to take it—I took it, and found there were only two sovereigns out of five—I said I would be one with him, 1 would have him taken up—I gave the bag up to the policeman, and the two sovereigns—I can swear I had five sovereigns in that bag when he came up to me—I had not taken them out, or changed one of them—I had twelve or fourteen in my pocket beside.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. What may you be? A. A bricklayer's labourer—I know the prisoner—we had been drinking toge
ther at the Two Brewers—I had received the five sovereigns on the 14th—I never saw them after twelve o'clock on the 22nd—the first public-house I went into was the Two Brewers, and the prisoner met me there, as I was going in—we staid there an hour, or it might be longer—we had two or three pots, perhaps—we then went to a beer-shop, about three o'clock, and remained till nine—we were there six hours—I paid for seven pots of ale, but several more came in—one had a glass, and another had a glass—we did not drink it ourselves—we smoked our pipes—I left first, and the prisoner came running after me—I could walk as well as 1 can now—the prisoner did not lead me—I did not want leading—I did not rest my arm on his—I never asked him to see me home, and say, after some time, "Let me try if I can't go alone," or put my hands into my pocket, and then reel down—he thrust me down—we only had one glass of gin apiece at the Two Brewers—I said, before the Magistrate, that the prisoner shook the bag in my face, and said, "Here is your money, Sam"—when I had fallen down, the prisoner endeavoured to help me up—after this occurred, the prisoner walked away from me—after I said he had robbed me, we walked about twenty yards together—Mrs. Edwards, the witness, knows me per
fectly well—I went home—I did not call a policeman—I could not find one—this was in Manor-lane, not 100 yards from the beer-shop, about 400 yards from Nelson-row, where I live—I slept that night where I lodge, which is at a beer-shop.

SARAH EDWARDS . I am the wife of William Edwards, a coal-dealer, in Little Manor-lane—at half-past nine o'clock in the evening, on the 22nd of October, I heard a person fall under my window—I looked out and saw Groves on the ground, and the prisoner's hand in his pocket—Groves said, "You have robbed me of my money"—the prisoner said he had not—I think the prisoner staid with him five or ten minutes, and then he dragged him across the road—I did not see any more of him.
Cross-examined. Q. Groves was very far gone, was he not? A. Not so far but he knew what he was about—he did not wish to be dragged, but

he could not get away—this is ray mark to this deposition—(read—"The said Sarah Edwards says, 'Last Tuesday night, at half-past nine, I heard some one fall under my window; on going out I saw Groves on the ground, and the prisoner stooping over him; the prisoner put his hand into Groves's right-hand trowsers-pocket; I saw nothing in his hand when he took it out; he put it into his own pocket; Groves said, 'You have robbed me;' the prisoner said he had not; my husband came out, picked up Groves's hat, and said to the prisoner, 'If you have robbed him, give it him, and don't take advantage of him;' Groves called to my husband to go with him; he said he would not.")

WILLIAM EDWARDS . I merely heard Groves cry out, "You have robbed me"—I ran out, and said, "Sam, what are you doing?"—I picked up his hat, and assisted him up—he said, "This man has robbed me"—I said, "If you have taken anything from him, return it to him"—the pri
toner did not make any answer—I followed them a few yards to the bottom of the place, and Groves was continually saying, "Follow me, he his taken my money"—I said, "I shall not follow you, if you have taken anything from him, give it him back."

Cross-examined. Q. Who is Billy Bokins? A. He keeps a beer-shop—Groves lodges there—they were then 400 or 500 yards from Bokins—I did not hear the prisoner say, "I have not robbed you, I have not got your money."
JOHN BRIDGES (police-constable V 194.) I apprehended the prisoner on the 24th of Nov., in the Clapham-road.

Cross-examined. Q. Did the prisoner come to you? A. No, he was just coming from Nelson-row—the prosecutor had not been to me, but he had given information—the prisoner said he had been to the prosecutor's, but he was not at home—I searched the prisoner at the station—I found on him 2s. 2d.—I went to his lodging in Robert-street, Stock well—I found nothing there.
NOT GUILTY .

185.
HENRY PLEASANT was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Oct., 11 yards of printed cotton, value 10s. the goods of
William Checker; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM CHECKER . I am a linen-draper, and live at Clapham. I had a piece of printed cotton safe at my door at half-past twelve o'clock on the 23rd of Oct.—I received information from a neighbour, and missed it be
tween twelve and one—this is it—it is mine.

JOHN BRIDGLAND . I am an omnibus conductor. On the 23rd of Oct., at ten minutes before one o'clock, I received information, and ran and caught the prisoner—he had this cotton—I saw him drop it—I said, "This don't belong to you"—he said, "No, I did not take it"—he was about 150 yards from Mr. Checker's—he ran part of the way, and then stood, and I came up to him.
Prisoner. There were two others with me who gave it to me.
HENRY NOLAN (police-constable L 129.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, by the name of Henry Jones—(read)—the prisoner is the person then tried.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years .

186.
JOHN HARVEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Nov., 6lbs. weight of ham, value 3s., the goods of
Henry Garrett; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM HELLEWELL . I am in the service of Mr. Henry Garrett, a cheesemonger—he lives in St. George the Martyr, Southwark. On the 14th of Nov. I placed two half hams inside the window at seven o'clock—I do not remember seeing them after that—I saw the prisoner at ten minutes before ten o'clock, about twenty yards from our window, with one of the half hams in his possession—I walked towards him—he saw me, and placed the half ham down by the side of a gateway—he walked on a short distance—I took up the ham, and was returning with it in my apron—the prisoner passed me, and I gave him into custody.

MARY WILKINSON . I am the wife of Joseph Wilkinson. On that evening I saw the prisoner take the ham out of the window which was open—he laid it down by the gateway, then came a few yards towards me, and turned back, and the young man directly gave him into custody.

JAMBS PERRY (police-constable M 60.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, which I got from the clerk of the Peace of Surrey—(read)—"Convicted on the 16th of March, 3rd Vict.; and transported for seven years"—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years .

187.
FREDERICK CHILD,
WILLIAM ROGERS , and
HENRY ROGERS
, were indicted for stealing, on the 20th of Nov., 1 trowel, value 3s., the goods of
Peter Dunn.

PETER DUNN . I am a plasterer, and live at Kennington. I was at work outside a building at Stock well on the 20th of Nov.—I had a trowel inside the room—I saw it safe at half-past twelve, when I returned from dinner, and missed it at three o'clock—I saw Child and another lad with him, in the road that day, and soon afterwards I saw William Rogers in the room where the trowel was—this is my trowel that I missed.
JURY. Q. How do you know it? A. When I bought it I took the handle off, and put this handle on, and filed it off myself—I can swear to it.

EDWARD WHITE . I am a labourer. I went to look after the prisoners—I saw Child with the trowel under his arm, and the other two prisoners were with him—I followed them, and Child went and pawned it at a pawnbroker's—I went to him when he came out, and asked him if he had seen the Rogers—he told me no, he had just come from Vauxhall-bridge—I told the pawnbroker to keep the trowel.

GEORGE MARK LINTHORNE . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this trowel, which was pawned by a boy, who I think was Child, but I cannot swear to him—White came and told me something in about a quarter of an hour.

Child. I met these two boys; they told me to go there and I could get a job; I went in, and was coming out, when I met William Rogers with the trowel, and he asked me to pawn it, which I did; I was not aware it was stolen.
William Rogers'Defence. He said he had no need of his trowel; he had no work, and would I go and get it for him, it laid on the floor; I went and got, it and he went and pawned it.
(Child received a good character.)

CHILD—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months .

WILLIAM ROGERS**—
GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Six Months and
Whipped .

HENRY ROGERS—
NOT GUILTY .

188.
ISAAC HOARE and
JOHN FLEMING were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 30th of Oct., two wooden boxes, value 2d., the goods of
Richard Herrington.

ANN HERRINGTON . I am the wife of Richard Herrington. We keep a shop at Wandsworth—we had some toy-boxes in a basket in the shop—I saw them safe between one and two o'clock in the day on the 30th of Oct.—I did not miss them till the officer came and brought these two between eight and nine o'clock at night—they are ours.
JOHN POTTER (police-constable V 118.) I took these boxes from Hoare—he said he had bought them that day, but he did not say where—Fleming was with him, but did not say anything.
Hoare. I bought them of two boys for 1d.

HOARE—
GUILTY .

FLEMING—
NOT GUILTY .

189.
ISAAC HOARE and
JOHN FLEMING were again indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of Oct., 1 pound cake, value 3d.; and 5 Banbury cakes, 5d.; the goods of
James Plumridge.
JAMES PLUMRIDGE . I am a baker, and live at Wandsworth. On the evening of the 30th of Oct. I missed five or six Banbury cakes and a pound cake—they have not been found.

JOHN HALL . I am pot-boy at the Two Brewers. About half-past eight o'clock at night, on the 30th of Oct., I was going out with beer—I saw Hoare with his hand in the prosecutor's window, and Fleming was with him—Hoare had some cakes and some tarts in his hand—they ran across the road together, and ran down Garret-lane.

ALFRED STACEY . I saw Hoare break the window—it was cracked, and he pushed it with his finger—the prisoners ran round the square, and threw the glass away—they then went back and took the cake and tarts out.
Hoare. It was John Webster broke the glass out, and he gave him lome of the tarts.
Witness. I did not see Webster.

HOARE*—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Four Months .

FLEMING*—
GUILTY . Aged 10.—
Confined One Month and
Whipped .

190.
ROBERT EDWARDS was indicted
for stealing 3 jackets, value 30s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 10s.; 1 shirt, 3s.; 1 handkerchief; 2s. 6d.; and 10lbs. weight of tobacco, 4s.; the goods of
John Dickenson, in a vessel in a port of entry and discharge.

JOHN DICKENSON . I am apprentice on board the Robert Bruce, which was lying off Rotherhithe. I had three jackets and these other articles safe on Monday, the 11th of Nov., between one and two o'clock—I missed them about six o'clock the same evening—these are them—these are all mine.
BENJAMIN HASELDINE . I am a pawnbroker. I produce one jacket,
which I took in pledge of the prisoner on the 11th of Nov., about seven o'clock in the evening.

JOHN EVANS (police-constable R 190.) I took the prisoner—I told him he was charged with breaking a box on board the Robert Bruce, and stealing these things—he said, "I own I pawned the jacket, but Reed gave it me"—I apprehended Reed, but we could find no evidence against him, and he was discharged—I found a pair of trousers and a silk handkerchief on the prisoner at the station, which the prosecutor identifies.

Prisoner. You asked me whether I pawned the jacket, and I said I did, and Reed gave it me. I was coming down the wall, and Reed said to me, "Will you pawn this jacket?" I said, "Yes, provided you stand some beer." I took the jacket; the man said he would lend me 3s. on it. I gave Reed the 3s. and the ticket; he said, "Never mind the ticket, I shan't get it any more."

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined Three Months .

191.
THOMAS SHILLUM and
JOHN KING were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of Nov., 1 bag, value 1s.; 28lbs. weight of shot, 5s.; the goods of
Joshua Walker and others, their masters.
MR. DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES RATCLIFF (City police-constable. No. 375.) On the evening of the 8th of Nov. I was on duty in Ludgate-street, between six and seven o'clock—I saw King carrying something—I followed him to the Old Bailey, and saw he had got something very heavy under his arm—when he got to the Sessions-house, I said, "What have you got here?"—he said, "It is all right, old fellow"—he said a party gave it him, and I might go and look for that party—I said, "No, I shall look to you"—he said, "I shall lose my place; for God's sake let me go"—he made two struggles to get away in the Old Bailey, but at last I succeeded in getting him to the station, and there I found it was this bag of shot which he was carrying, which has the name of "Walker, Parker, and Co." on it—I went to Messrs. Walker, Parker, and Co., and went with the foreman to Shillum, and took him to the station, and then King said that Shillum gave it him, but he asked him for it, and Shillum took it out of the ware-house.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When King was asked how be became possessed of it, did he not say that Shillum gave it to him to carry for him? A. No, he said he asked him for it—I heard Mr. Wardley ask Shillum where he got the bag, and I heard Shillum reply, "I took the bag of shot from the warehouse, and gave it to King."
MR. DOANE. Q. You heard King say, before that, that he got it from Shillum, but he asked him for it? A. Yes.

GEORGE WARDLEY . I am manager of the factory of Joshua Walker and others—King was our carman, and Shillum was in the white lead department—we have a shot department—persons can get from the white lead department to the shot department—Shillum had no business in the shot department with
out special orders—I remember King going away on the night of the 8th of November, about six o'clock—the policeman came afterwards, and I went with him to Shillum's house—I found him at home, and took him to the station—I left him outside—I went in and found King in custody—I saw this bag, with my employers'name on it—I asked King how he became

possessed of it—he said, "Shillum gave it me to carry a little way for him"—I went outside, and asked Shillum to go in—King then again repeated that Shillum gave him this bag of shot—I asked Shillum how he became possessed of it—he said, "I stole it from the warehouse, and gave it to him to carry a little way, but I was asked to do so"—this bag of shot is worth 5s.
Cross-examined. Q. How long has King been with you? A. Nearly two years—he has a wife, and I believe one daughter.

Shillum. Q. Did I hesitate to accompany you? A. Not at all—I left you outside the station-house, and found you there—I have entrusted you with notes, money, and checks, and always found you correct before—I did not say if you told the truth I would not cause you to be locked up—you were locked up before that—when you were at Union-hall, King sent for me, and wanted me to be merciful—I said there might be some mercy shewn them if they would tell their confederates, and what had been done previous to this.

MR. DOANE. Q. You found King and Shillum at Union-hall? A. I did not see Shillum—King said, "Master, I hope you won't punish me for this little offence; I hope you will forgive me"—I said, "I can't, it must be left to my employers."

Shillum's Defence. It was from an inducement held out to me by the prosecutor, that I stated what I did; several policemen stated that if I spoke the truth my master would not hurt roe; it was in consequence of that, and King saying that I gave it him, that I stated what I did, but I am inno
ccent of the transaction as a child.
James Brannan police-sergeant G 20, Joseph Seal, a coal-dealer, North-street, Finsbury, and Richard Phillips, a porter, in Turnraill-street, gave King a good character.

SHILLUM—
GUILTY . Aged 32.

KING—
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Confined Six Months .

192.
MARTHA TAYLOR and
GEORGE WILSON were indicted for
unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. DOANE and SCRIVEN conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS PICKETT . I am a chandler, and live at Upper Tooting. On the 16th of Nov., about four or five o'clock, Taylor came to my shop and purchased a small quantity of cheese, which came to fourpence half-penny—she gave me in payment a half-a-crown—I gave her the change—she did not speak, nor did I, but she took the two shillings, and left the three halfpence on the counter, and was going away—I called her back—she came and took the three halfpence, and I saw no more of her—I afterwards saw Mr. Barnett—I gave him the same half-crown, as I got from Taylor.
Wilson. Q. What did you do with the half-crown? A. I had it in my hand till Mr. Barnett came in—he marked it, and gave it me again—he came in not a minute after Taylor left.

MARY WOODS . I am the wife of Joseph Woods, a corn-chandler, at Balham-hill. On the 16th of Nov. Taylor came into my shop for a pint of hird-seed—it was rape and canary—it came to 3d.—she gave me a half-crown—I gave her 2s. 3d., and put the half-crown into my pocket—I am quite certain I had no other half-down in my pocket—Mr. Barnett came in with two constables—he wished to look at the half-crown, and I gave it
him—my shopman marked it in my presence—I had not received any other half-crown from the time Taylor came in.
Wilson. Q. Do you positively swear you did not put it into the till when you took it from the woman? A. Yes, I do.

JOHN BARNETT . I am a dairyman, and live at Lower Tooting, On the 16th of Nov., in the evening, I saw Taylor go into a shop—I went afterwards, and made inquiries—in consequence of what I was told I watched Taylor, and saw her join company with Wilson—they were in company side by side, and talking—I then saw Taylor go into Mr. Pickctt's shop—Wilson was on the opposite side—when Taylor came out she crossed, and joined him—I went into Mr. Pickett's, and received the half-crown which I marked—it was afterwards given to the officer—when I came out I saw the two prisoners again—Wilson was a little in advance of Taylor—she then went into two or three other shops, and when she came oat of them she joined Wilson, and they went on—I followed, and saw Taylor go into Wood's shop, and come out—I crossed over to Wilson, who I thought was watching me, and offered to sell him a little spaniel dog that I had—he said he did not want it—I walked a little way on, and saw he was standing waiting for Taylor—she joined him, and they walked up Balham-hill together—I met my brother-in-law, Passfield, and we looked out for a constable—we went to the Bedford Arms—the prisoners came up and I took Wilson, Passfield took Taylor.
Wilson. Q. Were we together when you first saw us? A. No—you joined company when Taylor came out of a house—you kept on together from Lower to Upper Tooting.

WILLIAM PASSFIELD . I am brother-in-law to Mr. Barnett. On the 16th of Nov. I met him on Balham-hill—I assisted him in watching the prisoners—I saw them together, and heard them in conversation—I could hear them talking, and it seemed to me that they were wrangling—I took Taylor—they were together at the time I took her.

GEORGE SPENCER DAWES (police-constable V 185.) I took the pri
soners at the Bedford Arms—I found on Wilson four shillings, a sixpence, 4 1/2 d. in copper, a small quantity of cheese, and a small quantity of bird-seed, which was rape and canary mixed—I found on Taylor four shil
lings, two sixpences, and 4d. in copper—I produce the two half-crowns, the one from Mrs. Wood, and the other which was passed at Mr. Pickett's

MART WOODS
re-examined. This is the same sort of seed that I sold to Taylor—I sold her a pint—here is not quite a pint.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These half-crowns are both counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.

TAYLOR—
GUILTY . Aged 21—
Confined Three Months .

WILSON—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year .

193.
HENRY PERFECT and
JOHN PERFECT were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of Oct., 1 pillow, value 2s.; 3 locks, 1s. 6d.; 1 coach-spring, 1l.; 2 sacks, 3s.; part of a scythe, 4d.; 2 knives, 6d.; 1 punch, 2d.; 1 pair of tongs, 1s.; 1 shovel, 6d.; 1 file, 6d.; part of a desk-flap, 5s.; 1 collar, 1s.; 6 coach-bolts, 1s.; 1 cupboard-door, 5s.; 2 blocks for springs, 2s.; and 1 piece of wood, 6d.; the goods of
Joseph Skinner.
JOSEPH SKINNER . I am an auctioneer and appraiser, and live at No. 33, Park-place, New Peckham. A fortnight before Michaelmas last I took a

cottage, of which Henry Perfect was keeping possession for the landlord—I put in a large quantity of my property about a week before Michaelmas—Henry Perfect was then in the house, and a person whom I believed to be his wife—the articles stated in the indictment were among the things I put in—I have lost a great many things, and have only found a few of them—I have not had anything to do with them since I put them in—I have been in the country—I know nothing of John Perfect, more than his coming two or three times with some potatoes to his brother—he came with a horse and cart—Henry said he hoped I should excuse his taking the liberty of putting his brother's horse and cart in the place—on the 1st of Nov. the things were gone from the house—those that are here, and a number of others.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How long have you had these things? A. The principal part for years—this is part of a spring belong
ing to a phaeton I had—I found it when I went in pursuit of Henry, who ran sway—I went to his brother's house at Singlewell, thinking he might be there, and there found this spring—it was fixed to a cart of John Per
feet's—I know it quite well, and I know this part of a scythe—it is part of a scythe which came with a lot of things which I was a great loser by, and it was bound up with some tar cord—it had no handle to it then, but it had the same notch in it which it has now—it is in a very different state now—I know this file—it is a very unusual sort, such as I never saw in my life before—I purchased it, and found great fault with it—the point was broken off—this piece of wood is a desk-flap—I bought a desk with four flaps to it, and I have only one left—this has been matched to it, and this part exactly fits where it was taken from—I found this at John Per
fect's, in a shed which they call an oil place—my son went and saw John carry sway his own furniture from the cottage, and some other things which my son could not see—I had some complaints and suspicions against Henry which took me to John's place—I took handcuffs with me—I am a parish constable—I have nothing to do as a constable at Gravesend, near to where I took him—I handcuffed him—he has not been very ill in conse
quence of that—if I had not had assistance I should have lost my life—I hare a witness to show where he struck me on the head—I cannot recol
lect what he said—if he did not deny that the property was mine, it was to that purpose.

COURT. Q. When you got down to John Perfect's what did you do? A. I had his master with me, who charged him with robbing him of po
tatoes and straw—I asked for his brother—he said he had just heard, last night, that his brother was in custody, and when he found I was going to take him into custody, and put the handcuffs on him, he struck me over the head with the bit of the scythe.

MR. DOANE. Q. Did he ask if you had any warrant? A. No—he might have said something about a warrant afterwards, when he was at a public-house—I do not know a boot and shoemaker at Paddington—I ne
ver did—I do not know a man who had a lodging in South Moulton-lane, Davis-street—there was a man named Hiscock, who rented a shoemaker's stall of me—the account there states he was a little in arrears—I distrained upon him, but not for a little rent—his rent was 4s. a week, and be owed me 5l.—I did not take his apron off—I took his coat, but not off his per
son—I took his tools—his spectacles were taken with the other things, not off his person—I have heard that he hung himself from the effects of

drunkenness—I do not know that the Jury expressed indignation at my conduct—I was not there—I have seen in the paper that they did, and I have been to the office of the Times to-day about it—you will see a diffe
rent statement to-morrow.

COURT. Q. Are you sure that the things you found at John Perfect's are yours? A. Yes—I have brought another spring to match this one—I know this pillow, and believe it to be mine—this is one of my sacks—I claimed two at John Perfect's—this one was cut open and laid upon the ground—this has the maker's name on it.
SUSANNAH FRANKLIN . I went to the station with Mr. Skinner—I know this pillow and tongs.

THOMAS BENJAMIN BAKER SKINNER . I went to Rose Cottage, and the prisoners were loading a cart—I could not discover what things were in it—I did not stop—John Perfect drove it—when I went back the things at the bottom were all covered over, and then they put their own things on the top—they had got some of their own things there.

Cross-examined. Q. You were present during the whole time they loaded the cart? A. No—I went after they had got a good many things in the bottom of the cart—I then went home and told my mother, and then went back—John Perfect saw me—I do not know whether the things he carried away were his own or not.
Henry Perfect's Defence. I could take my solemn oath that my brother did not take them away.
MR. SKINNER re-examined. John Perfect occupied the cottage near Gravesend, and Henry was at Rose-cottage.

BETSY WALKER . I live at Northfleet, and get my living by labour. I know John Perfect—I have been working with him there for four months—this pillow they have had ever since I knew them—here is one particu
lar mark that I know it by, a piece of black thread at one corner.
JOSEPH SKINNER I wish to know what did you say to me in reference to the pillow when I was at the house.
Witness. I said one was fuller than the other, and this one they had when they first came down—I was there when they came—the cart only came once—he and his wife both came.
MR. SKINNER re-examined. It was on the Tuesday after the 1st. of Nov. that I took the goods at Gravesend—Henry Perfect's goods were not mixed with mine—I put mine in a room separate.
NOT GUILTY .

194.
HENRY PERFECT was again indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Nov., 6 wooden lathes, value 2s.; 2 bed-sackings, 2s.; 1 wooden cart-seat, seat, 1s.; 1 rug, 3s.; 3 boxes, 3s.; 3 picture-frames, 4s.; 1 looking-glass and frame, 8s.; 2 shovels, 2s.; 1 poker, 10s.; 60lbs. weight of feathers, 3l.; 12 yards of bed-tick, 5s.; 9 yards of printed cotton, 5s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 2s.; 1 gauge, 6d.; 1 mahogany stool-top, 1s.; 1 clock-winder, 6d.; 1 ring, 4d.; 20lbs. weight of nails, 5s.; 1 ink-glass, 6d.; 1 staff, 6d.; 2 curtain-pins, 1s.; 18 pairs of hinges, 6d.; 1000 brads. 2s.; 1 brush, 6d.; 2 screw-drivers, 1s.; 1 gauge, 4d.; 1 rule, 6d.; I saw, ls.; 1 pocket-book, 1s.; 4 wooden caddy-feet, 1s.; 2 handles, 6d.; 1 latch, 6d.; 5 locks, 6d.; 2 yards of carpet, 4s.; 1 Chain, 1s.; 1 pillow, 1s.; 1 table, 5s.; 8 yards of stained paper, 1s.; 50 yards of cotton binding, 1s. 6d.; 1 basket, 6d.; 1 awl, 2d.; 1 curtain, 1s.; 2 printed books, 2s.; 1 memorandum, 1s.; 3 pictures, 3s.; 1 watch-stand, 1s.; and 1 tea-caddy, 1s.; the goods of Joseph Skinner.

JOSEPH SKINNER . I live in Park-place. The prisoner was in posses
sion of Rose-cottage—I left these things there, and afterwards missed them and a great many more—I went to where the prisoner lived, near Peck
ham, and found all these things—they are mine.
HENRY HOLTON (policeman.) I went to this place at Peckham, and found this property—the prisoner said nothing to me—he made his escape.

Prisoner's Defence. A gentleman I was at work for put me into this house; the prosecutor came and asked the rent of the house; I told him; he said he should want it, that he should sow the ground with grass, and would give me the job, and that he would give me 2s. 6d. a week, and coals and candles; I said I was obliged, and would stay; he then brought a horse, and said might he be put into the stable; I said I did not know, he must ask Mr. Hudson, the proprietor; he then brought these things, and soon after went into the country; Mr. Hudson came, and said what busi
ness had I to let Mr. Skinner have possession of the house; then Mr. Skinner came, and said what should he give me to take care of the horse; I said 2s. a week; I worked all day, till twelve o'clock at night, and got no recompense; he then came and found fault with the things; he asked my wife for a screw-driver, got her into the shed, fastened the door, and would not let her pass; he said, "You had better leave, I am going to leave." I said, "When do you move?" he said, "This week." I said, "You had better take these things." My wife gave him a bill, but he did not pay it; he came and said, "I want you to go and seize on a shoe-maker;" I refused; I came back in the evening, and he said, "Your wife has given me another bill, when are you going to move?" I went and found all my things packed up, and he said he would lend me a horse and cart to take them in; we put the things in one comer of the room, and when I opened them I found I had got these things; I thought he might have put them in for the money he owed me; I did not see them packed up.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Year .
Before Mr. Recorder.

195.
JOHN RICHARDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Nov., at Lambeth, 17 half-sovereigns, the monies of
William Ridgyard, the elder, in his dwelling-house: and 1 shirt, value 4s., and 16 sovereigns, the property of
William Ridgyard, jun.

WILLIAM RIDGYARD, JUN . I live at No. 29, Gibson-street, in the parish of Lambeth—it is the dwelling-house of my father, William Ridg-yard, the elder—he is the tenant of the whole house—the prisoner is my brother—he did not live in the house—he did so about a year and a half ago, but had left, and had been forbidden the house—on the 13th of Nov. I had sixteen sovereigns of my own, and seventeen half-sovereigns of my father's, safe in a box which was locked, and was kept in my bedroom in the upper part of the house—on the 16th of Nov., about half-past eleven at night, I discovered that the lid of the box had been moved, and the bot
tom wrenched out, and the money all gone—I also missed a shirt and
handkerchief of my own—no one but myself occupied that bedroom—I always kept the door locked during the day—I found it locked—I always carried the key in my pocket.

ELIZABETH SPINKS . I am the wife of Edward Spinks, a dyer, and lodge in the prosecutor's house—on Thursday, the 14th of Nov., I saw the prisoner unlocking the room door where the last witness slept—he went in, and remained about half an hour—the door was not closed—it was ajar—I was standing in the passage on the same floor—ours is the next room—I heard him come out—he shut and locked the door, and went down stairs—I saw him clearly, and am certain it was the prisoner—on Satur
day, day, the 16th, my husband went out at the street door, about twenty mi
nutes past three, and I heard a man come in and go up stairs—I heard him unlock this bedroom door, and go in—I did not hear him come out—I do not know who that was—I was in the adjoining room all the evening.
Prisoner. Q. At what time did you see me go and unlock this door? A. Between twelve and one on the Thursday.
Prisoner. I was not near the place on the Thursday.

Witness. I knew him by sight before, and knew he was the landlord's son—he was in the habit of coming to the house latterly—I saw him for about a month coming there often once or twice a day—he used to stand outside the door, and when he saw a lodger go in or out he used to whip in at the door—he was not in the habit of doing so to the family—he used to go down into the kitchen when he came in—his father works at a shop-when he is at home he resides in the parlour—I never saw the prisoner in the parlour—he used to go down into the kitchen—his father and mother sleep there—she used to see him come in sometimes—he did not find his mother in the kitchen when he went there—I do not know whether there was any one there.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see me go down into the kitchen? A. Yet—I have several times—I have heard him knock at the street door, and seen him standing at the door when I have gone out, and he has come in at the time—I did not myself see the person who came in when my husband went out—my husband did—he is not here.

DAVID WEAVER (police-constable F 28.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody—a person named Blake said in his presence that he had a deal of money—he said, "It is a lie, I have no money whatever"—after that he said he had a few shillings—fourteen sovereigns, twelve half-sovereigns, and 1l. 3s. 6d. in silver, was found in his jacket pocket.

CHARLES HENRY BIGNEL (police-constable F 31.) I searched the pri
soner in the cell when he was in custody, and found a shirt upon him, which I have here.

WILLIAM RIDGYARD
re-examined. This is my shirt—it had been in the box where the money was put—I am sure of that—I bad seen it there on Wednesday, the 13th—it was the only shirt I had in the box—I know it by the buttons—I had sewn two of them on myself—I am able to swear it was in the box on the Wednesday—I had no mark on the money—I am not aware why Mr. Spinks is not here—the prisoner's mother partly sanctioned his coming backwards and forwards—I and my father did not—he was in the habit of coming to see his mother—he used to work for us a year and a half, or two years back—since then he has had nothing to do, and he has been in the habit of coming backwards and forwards, and
breaking into the place—my father and I wished him kept away from the house, on account of his previous bad actions.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined One Year .

Before
Edward Bullock, Esq,

196.
JOHN PIERCY was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining goods and money by false pretences.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant,

197.
EDWARD GARROOD was indicted
for obtaining money by false pretences.

ANTHONY CHAPMAN (police-constable V 100.) I reside at Tooting, in Surrey. On Sunday, the 3rd of Nov., about twelve or one o'clock, the prisoner brought a parcel to my house—he had been conductor to an om
nibus—on the paper parcel he brought there was "2s. 2d." marked, and he demanded 3s. 2d. for the carriage—it had come from the New Inn, Old Bailey—I said, "3s. 2d.?"—he said, "Yes, here is the bill, 2s. 2d. paid out, and 1s. carriage"—my sister-in-law paid him the 3s. 2d. in my presence—unless I had believed that "2s. 2d." had been paid out, and 1s. was due for carriage, I should not have paid it.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did you say you thought it was too much? A. I did—I thought the whole of it was too much—I believe the prisoner was in the service of Mr. Holden, the omnibus pro
prietor—after he was gone, it struck me there had been an alteration in the bill, from 1 to 2—the prisoner was not taken for ten days afterwards—he was not in the town.

JAMES MILLER . I am in the service of the Merton carrier. On Sun
day, the 3rd of Nov., in the morning, my master gave me a parcel, directed to Mr. Chapman—I carried it to Tooting—the prisoner came up to me, and asked where I was going—I said to Mr. Chapman's, and I asked him if he could tell me where it was—he said he would go with me and take it—I said I should be very glad if he could assist me—the money he ought to have received on that parcel was 2s. 6d.—there was 1s. 2d. marked on the bill, and 1s. 4d. was the carriage from London—I gave him the parcel to take—we got to Mr. Chapman's, and he took it in—I gave him the bill—this is it—it has been altered from 1s. 2d. to 2s. 2d.

Cross-examined. Q. When you first saw him, did you not ask where Mr. Chapman lived? A. He asked me where I was going, and then I asked him where Mr. Chapman lived—it was on Tooting-common I gave him the parcel to deliver—he went to one Mr. Chapman, which was not right—he brought me the parcel out, and still kept possession of the bill—we went on as far as the church, and then he took the parcel, and said he knew where it was—he was gone four or five minutes, and then came back, and brought me half-a-crown—James Pincott and Thomas Tappin were with me on the common—I was in Mr. Pincott's service, but have left, to go to a public-house—I gave Mr. Pincott a week's notice—he kept me till I got a place—I have never been at Brixton or Guildford, nor in any gaol at all—I do not mean to swear that I never told anybody so, but I have never been there—I might have said it to some of the boys on
Tooting-common, but it was not so—I do not know that I have said so—I might.

JOSEPH REED (police-constable V 243.) I took the prisoner on Tooting common—he laid down on his back, and asked me what I wanted with him—I told him he knew—he said, "I know nothing but the parcel I took to Chapman"—I said, "That was all wrong"—he said, "I gave Miller the money."
(Edmund Craven, a wheelwright, and Ellen Simpson, of Tooting, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months .
ADJOURNED TO THE 16TH OF DECEMBER, 1844.
